TG-ASC140011.name: TG-ASC140011
TG-ASC140011.project_abstract: This proposal requests computational time on Stampede to support a course (Spring 2014, UTEP, CS 5334 Parallel and Concurrent Programming). This course introduces parallel and concurrent programming to graduate students and senior undergraduates and will require high performance computational resources to complete a lab exercise and a project. The course covers a range of topics, including shared memory, message passing, and hybrid MPI+threads programming, and the term project will involve work with a large-scale parallel application. Details of the estimate for required resources can be found in the supporting document.
TG-ASC140011.pi_institution: University of Texas at El Paso

TG-DMR080058N.name: TG-DMR080058N
TG-DMR080058N.project_abstract:
Materials currently used in micro-electronic and photovoltaic devices are either rapidly reaching their limits of applicability, or display poor efficiencies to allow for cost-effective manufacture and usage.  Notable examples include (1) SiO2 gate dielectrics in MOSFETs, with thickness reaching less than 2 nm in the latest processors, preventing further scaling,  and (2) Si based solar cells that display less than 25% solar-to-electrical energy conversion efficiencies (and so cannot meet the DOE cost/performance standards).   New materials, and materials design motifs, are required to address these urgent problems.

In the problems identified above, the electronic structure at the interface between dissimilar materials, and their stability, play pivotal roles in determining many critical device properties. For instance, in MOSFETs, the interface between the Si substrate and the gate dielectric has to be stable, be devoid of defect states, and display at least a 1 eV nested (or Type I) valence and conduction band offsets to allow for minimal leakage currents across the gate stack. The interfacial stability and electronic structure are also critical in heterojunction quantum dots or quantum wires which are expected to lead to next-generation photovoltaic devices.  Here, a Type II (or staggered) offset between the conduction and valence bands of two different semiconductor materials on either sides of an interface is a requirement for efficient dissociation of photo-generated electron-hole pairs.

Regardless of the specific application, it is important and useful to be able to reliably determine the atomic level physical structure across an interface between dissimilar materials, which is the starting point to compute their electronic structure (e.g., the valence and conduction band offsets). The main focus of the PI's efforts so far has been in the use of density functional theory (DFT) based techniques to study the stability, defect chemistry and electronic structure of a wide variety of interfaces, as described here. DFT simulations involving a few tens to hundred atoms have become somewhat commonplace today in most home-built linux clusters. Nevertheless, several interfacial systems relevant to the PIs research involve much larger systems containing few to several hundred atoms, and comprehensive studies of such systems will require a significantly larger infrastructure than is available locally at the PIs group.

This proposal reviews work performed in the PI's group using the current teragrid allocation, and describes the proposed work in the next year for which teragrid time is requested.

TG-CTS090004.name: TG-CTS090004
TG-CTS090004.project_abstract: The goal of this research is twofold: (i) to understand the role of turbulence in the generation of sound in modern aircraft turbo-machinery, and (ii) to develop computational methods for controlling the sound.   It is well known that certain geometrical modifications to aircraft engines can reduce their radiated noise.  However, there is no manner to predict which modifications will actually reduce the noise, resulting in lengthy---and costly---experimental programs to parametrically study candidate design modifications.  This deficiency is due to the conceptual, experimental, and computational challenges associated with turbulence-generated sound and, hence, in developing effective control methods.  By solving the compressible Navier-Stokes equations directly, this research provides foundational descriptions of the sound-generating fluid motions and subsequent development of optimized control methodologies.  The PI's code is based on advanced finite difference techniques and scales at 90\% of perfect up to 1024 processors on TACC's Ranger.  This work follows up the previous DACs TG-CTS080019 (DJB) and TG-CTS080030N (JBF).  Financial support for this work is provided by three separate grants from NASA and the AeroAcoustics Research Consortium on which the current investigators are PI's or co-PI.  It builds upon large-scale aeroacoustic simulation work from past NASA and AFOSR grants.  Total requested allocation is 14,000K SUs.

Educational-MECH6372.name: Educational-MECH6372
Educational-MECH6372.project_abstract: The aim of the project is to give hands on experience to the students on analysis of turbulent flows. I will run basic simulations of the flow in a turbulent channel, a turbulent jet and the students will develop parallel codes to analyze the results (statistical analysis, mean, rms, correlations, spectra).

TG-MCA00N020.name: TG-MCA00N020
TG-MCA00N020.project_abstract:
In this 3rd year of our 3 year LRAC proposal with our state-of -the-art code ORION, a parallel, 3D, adaptive mesh refinement (AMR) radiation-magnetohydrodynamics (RMHD) code with self-gravity, we will continue to address some of the leading questions in modern day star formation.  Building upon the substantial advancements we have made in the first 2 years of this LRAC award, we will continue our simulations of high mass star formation by extending our study of collapse and fragmentation of turbulent cores with no outflows and single-frequency radiation to explore a larger number of realizations and a wider range of parameters.
We will include for the first time, the combined effect of feedback from radiation and its interaction with feedback from protostellar outflows in an effort to pin down a mapping between the properties of cores and their environments such as column density, and the masses and multiplicities of the stellar systems to which they collapse.  The first exploratory simulations with ionization will be performed. We will also continue our ground breaking studies of multiple low mass star formation by studying the collapse of magnetized turbulent clumps with AMR and comparing results to our pure hydrodynamic models to gauge the role of magnetic fields in the star formation process. In addition, we will perform the same simulation with a 1000 solar mass turbulent clump that we have used in our current studies of star formation in turbulent clumps (Offner, Klein and McKee, 2008) but with magnetic fields. This study, now including magnetic fields, will complement our studies of core and star formation this current year without fields and enable us to delineate the effects of magnetic fields on star formation. To explore the effects of outflows on low mass star formation, we will also perform high-resolution AMR simulations of cluster formation including the feedback from such outflows using stellar evolutionary and wind feedback models. To do these simulations we will take advantage of our implementation of sink particles in Eulerian grids, which we have previously used to handle stellar evolution and feedback in our studies of high mass star formation. We will continue simulations of low mass star formation with radiative transfer, thereby addressing the effect of radiation feedback on core fragmentation and stellar multiplicity, first using our grey flux-limited implementation (GFLD) in ORION and then comparing with simulations using our newly developed Multi-Frequency Grey radiation transfer.  Finally, we will implement a new constrained transport Godunov algorithm for MHD in ORION and combine this with our newly developed approach to non-ideal MHD for our future explorations of turbulent core collapse driven by ambipolar diffusion.

TG-MCB140107.name: TG-MCB140107
TG-MCB140107.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB140107.project_abstract:
Proteins are the building blocks of life. They are important cellular scaffolds, signaling molecules, and chemical catalysts.  Our research objectives are to understand the folding (self-assembly), dynamics, and stability of proteins. To this end we use computational and theoretical approaches based on statistical mechanics, with particular emphasis on atomistic molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The application of computer simulations to molecular models grounded in physical principles allows us to obtain dynamic insights in atomistic details that are currently inaccessible by any other method.
This application deals with the use of atomistic, explicit solvent models of biomolecular systems and are directly related to human disease, HIV transmission modulated by amyloidogenic peptide found in semen. These systems include amyloid forming peptides of PAPf39 and Sem1f and serve in addition as a tractable model system for understanding intrinsically disordered proteins.  
In this proposal, we take advantage of the unprecedented opportunity for large-scale sampling presented by XSEDE, in conjunction with highly-optimized molecular dynamics code and efficient sampling algorithms, to reach new milestones in the detailed atomistic description of biomolecular processes and to validate these models against available experimental data. Together, these studies will help bridge the gap between microscopic and macroscopic scales of important biological processes and provide meaningful new insight into the molecular basis of human health and disease.

TG-DMR150040.name: TG-DMR150040
TG-DMR150040.project_abstract:
The combination of several newly discovered 2D materials into van der Waals heterostructures utilizes synergies in their structural and electronic properties to unlock new applications in optoelectronics, sensors, and composite materials. Liquid-phase self-assembly provides a facile and scalable route for the production of these heterogenous stacks of layered 2D materials. However, despite the wide spread usage of liquid phase exfoliation and stabilization for a variety of layered nanomaterials, there is still a lack of understanding of the role of the molecular structure and ordering in the exfoliation medium. 

Through all-atomistic molecular dynamics simulations, we intend to elucidate the significance of several molecular-level descriptors, including bulkiness, geometry, enhanced intermolecular cohesion, and ordering, of commonly used nanomaterial solvents in the aggregation of nanomaterial flakes. From these computational investigations, we hope to determine design rules to identify solvents which are most conducive to the self-assembly of a given ordered stack of 2D nanomaterials.

A-aoag.name: A-aoag
A-aoag.project_abstract: I propose a continuation of our AFOSR work related  to novel passive textures  for turbulent boundary layer control.  The devices of interest use shapes that  are small and closely spaced and hence require detailed direct numerical  simulation of the near surface flow to capture the physics.  We have already carried out simulations of configurations involving  synthetic jets and of small wall jets blowing/sucking below a turbulent boundary layer  to manipulate individual coherent flow structures.  In particular, I propose to continue to use our CFD approach  to investigate the use of riblets to constrain the development  of local turbulent regions.  In the late stages of boundary layer transition to turbulence, turbulent spots  may form.  As a turbulent spot moves downstream, it spreads laterally  until it merges with other growing spots and the entire span becomes turbulent.  Although the spots themselves have an interesting structure,   they appear much like small arrowhead-shaped  regions of fairly developed turbulence and so should be subject   to means of control  already developed for a fully turbulent boundary layer.  Although the development of spots of turbulence may be unavoidable,  perhaps their growth can be constrained by a riblet covered surface.  So even though having riblets covering much of an aircraft surface where the bou  ndary layer is  already turbulent does not usually pay off, riblets applied locally to extend th  e end of the laminar  region have greater potential leverage since there is such   a large increase in shear stress  in a turbulent flow and since small areas of riblets are cheap.    We are directly simulating this process. The direct numerical simulations  of the Navier Stokes equations are done in a channel-like domain   that is very long  in the streamwise direction. The emphasis of the work is on studying  the fundamental nature of the flows generated during the transition process  and how such small scale textures interact with the turbulent vortex  structures in a wall-bounded flow.    We have also begun a project to model rarefied atmospheric flows on our  moon after a comet impact an on Jupiter's moon Io. On Io, flows of sulfur  dioxide gas arise from sublimating frost patches and from active volcanic  plumes. We simulate these types of plumes with a direct simulation Monte  Carlo method.    Our codes now run well in parallel. The turbulent flow codes run in OpenMP  on Champion and the stochastic molecular codes in MPI on Champion or Lonestar.

TG-DMR160012.name: TG-DMR160012
TG-DMR160012.project_abstract:
Design of new materials for efficient electronics and optoelectronics relies on understanding their excited-state electronic structure, i.e. how light absorption, charge transfer, and charge transport relate to their chemical and solid-state structure. Here, we propose first-principles computational studies aimed at understanding the spectroscopic properties of inorganic wide gap ionic semiconductors and two-dimensional graphene-like materials. For both of these technologically-relevant classes of materials, the relatively strong electron correlation effects, localized charge density, and lack of understanding of the role of structure pose a challenge to first-principles theory. Utilizing a methodology based on the interacting Greens function formalism of many-body perturbation theory (MBPT) within the GW approximation and the Bethe-Salpeter equation (BSE) approach, we aim to understand 1) how naturally present defects influence the optoelectronic properties of the wide gap semiconductor gallium nitride (GaN) and 2) the electronic and optical properties of a monolayer of two-dimensional boron. These studies will provide new understanding of the behavior of these poorly understood materials and the tunability of their optoelectronic properties.

GaN is a promising wide gap semiconductor for power electronics and lighting applications. However, GaN films grow with high defect densities, and therefore understanding the relationship between structural defects and optoelectronic function will be central to the design of new high-performance materials. Building upon previous studies that utilized start-up hours on XSEDE, we will characterize the influence of carbon substitution in GaN films on its electronic and optical properties; here, the presence of C is known to result in increased resistivity within high power electronics and modified luminescent properties of light emitting diodes. While the ground state properties of GaN in the presence of defects have previously been explained through first-principles, optical excitations remain poorly understood. Our calculations will be particularly important for understanding the role of C-substitution in the degradation of GaN-based light emitting diodes.

While two-dimensional boron is a promising new transparent conductor for nanoelectronic applications, possibly replacing graphene in such applications, its optical properties have not been characterized. Here, we will utilize computational resources on Stampede to compute accurate bandstructures and optical excitations within this promising material. Additionally, two-dimensional boron ("borophene") has only been synthesized on metallic substrates; we will determine how bonding of the material with metal influences its structure and its optoelectronic properties. This project aims to fill a gap in understanding regarding the interaction of borophene with light.

TG-AST140024.name: TG-AST140024
TG-AST140024.project_abstract:
We request a total of 13.72* 10^6 SUs on the Austin machine Stampede to conduct 3D radiation-hydro and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations of three 
different astrophysics systems. Each project will be able to answer one long-standing question with the most accurate radiation transfer algorithm.

First, global radiation MHD simulations of black hole (BH) accretion disks. These simulations can tell us the global structures of radiation dominated accretion disks by calculating the turbulence from magneto-rotational instability (MRI) and radiation transfer self-consistently. Our goal is to study how the thermal instability in the radiation pressure dominated regime changes the structures of the disk. By changing the accretion rate, we will also be able to study three different kinds of accretion flows. Specific intensities from these simulations will be able to compare with observations directly. The new radiation transfer algorithm we have developed is a significant improvement over traditional diffusion approximation or M1 closure. 

Second, dynamics of the super-Eddington envelope of massive stars. These simulations will
explore convection in the radiation pressure dominated regime, including the stability of 
a density inversion that  develops due to super-Eddington radiation flux.
The primary objective is to constrain the  poorly understood structure and stability of massive star envelopes, which in turns will help to understand the physics of mass loss. 
This is expected to significantly improve our understanding of the evolution and death of massive stars.

Third, radiation feedback on giant molecular clouds (GMCs). We will calculate the evolution and disruption of GMCs under irradiation from young stars. As radiation feedback is believed to play an important role in the regulation of the star formation rate in the galaxies, these simulations will allow us to better assess and quantify the role of radiation forces and heating.  In particular,  we will better understand how radiation couples with dust and gas in star forming environments, with the aim of improving the sub-grid models in large scale cosmological simulations. 

All the three projects require accurate treatment of the radiation transfer, 
and coupling both the radiation energy and momentum source terms to the MHD equations.     
We have developed two new radiation-transfer modules in the well-tested MHD code Athena 
so that we can use the best suitable method for each project. Our calculations do not make the approximations used by other radiation hydro/MHD simulations in the literature (such as flux limited diffusion and M1).  As a result, we are the only group utilizing the full solution of the radiation transfer equation to study key astrophysical radiation hydro/MHD problems.

Nanowires.name: Nanowires
Nanowires.project_abstract: Modeling and simulation of Nano-wires as photovoltaic devices.

TG-DMR090006.name: TG-DMR090006
TG-DMR090006.project_abstract:
As part of an academic/industrial collaborative effort between the University of Illinois and General Motors R\&D through NSF's GOALI program, we are beginning a computational study of dislocation/solute interactions in HCP metals, specifically for the critical problem of building accurate deformation models for magnesium alloys.  We model pure Mg dislocation geometries and properties, as well as the effects of Al solutes via two main tasks: 1. determining the dislocation core for basal and non-basal dislocations in pure Mg at zero and finite stress using density-functional theory with flexible boundary conditions; 2. substituting Al at sites around the Mg dislocation cores to determine solute/dislocation interactions with density-functional theory.  Key to this work are high-performance computing resources to perform the study.

The objective of this study is to apply electronic-structure methods for the study of dislocations for Mg and Mg alloys and incorporate this data into finite-element constitutive models.  Connecting fundamental electronic structure studies of deformation at the atomistic scale to finite element modeling for new alloy design and direct incorporation in industrial usage is a potentially transformative concept in materials science and engineering.  It offers the promise to move beyond traditional trial-and-error approaches, and the combined talents of the academic-industrial collaboration is uniquely positioned to approach this problem.  Computational resources from TeraGrid combined with dedicated local resources are necessary to expand the work to enough dislocation types, stresses, and solute sites to provide meaningful data.

Peridynamics-and-fin.project_abstract: This project is to support our 3-D simulations using both Peridynamics and finite volume codes.

TG-MCB140274.name: TG-MCB140274
TG-MCB140274.project_abstract: Influenza is one of the most wide spread diseases and severely affects the health of millions of human beings annually. Our lab computationally studies Influenza hemagglutinin (HA2), the homotrimeric viral surface protein that facilitates host-viral membrane fusion both by introducing its fusion peptides into the host membrane and through a large conformational rearrangement. Our coarse-grained studies have brought up interesting questions that are important in order to understand the molecular mechanism of membrane fusion mediated by HA2. Here, to address these questions, we request a total of 4.7 million SUs on Stampede supercomputer, to perform explicit-solvent molecular dynamics simulations with a newly developed single-copy enhanced sampling method and the CHARMM36 force field. Project 1 needs 2.5 million SUs to map out the free energy landscape of the B-loop domain of HA2, which undergoes a loop-to-coiled-coil transition that presents the fusion peptides to the host membrane. There is much controversy in the field as to whether the B-loop is enthalpically-downhill driven (spring-loaded), or whether there is a significant entropic barrier to its transition. Our simulations will conclusively discern the mechanism of this transition. Project 2 needs 2.2 million SUs to address the dynamics and structure of fusion peptides once they have been introduced into the host membrane. Through simulations, we will find out whether the fusion peptides aggregrate, form a specific functional oligomer, or simply provide an anchor for HA2. Prospective results from these two projects will shed light on the generic membrane fusion mechanism shared by influenza viruses and other viruses such as HIV and Ebola. Additionally, an understanding of the molecular mechanism for fusion will highlight the vulnerable regions of HA2 on which to concentrate drug research.

High-Dimensional-Bay.name: High-Dimensional-Bay
High-Dimensional-Bay.project_abstract: This project estimates several high dimensional Bayesian panel vector auto regression models. The unit of observations is countries and the data frequency is monthly. This time series model is used to answer questions related to effects of United States shocks on other countries.

TG-EAR140013.name: TG-EAR140013
TG-EAR140013.project_abstract: The goal of our research is to use coupled discrete element-fluid simulations to explore and illuminate the controls on the dynamics of crystal mushes. Crystal mushes are multiphase systems that are particle rich, with an interstitial viscous fluid phase. We now understand that these mushes are the factory from which volcanic products and portions of the Earths crust, and other silicate planets, are produced]. Crystal-rich mixtures can manifest a remarkable diversity of rheological states, self-organization and threshold behavior such as jamming,  enduring contact, sliding, collision or rapid fluidization and mobilization, and also exhibit surprisingly efficient mixing, all under low-Reynolds number conditions. Thus they can have a remarkable diversity of responses to a small number of dynamic degrees of freedom, hence there is no unifying theory of dense (particle-rich) mixtures.

TG-MCA95C006.name: TG-MCA95C006
TG-MCA95C006.project_abstract: The Center for Analysis and Prediction of Storms CAPS), a graduated NSF S&T center, continues to maintain a vibrant program of basic and applied research in storm-scale data assimilation and numerical weather prediction (NWP).  CAPS leads the University of Oklahomas participation as a core research partner in an NSF Engineering Research Center (ERC) for Collaborative Adaptive Sensing of Atmosphere (CASA).  CAPS also leads an multi-institution NSF Large Information Technology Research (ITR) project, known as Linked Environments for Atmospheric Discovery (LEAD), that seeks to develop an infrastructure for mesoscale meteorology research and education. Other funded projects include storm-scale data assimilation centered around ensemble Kalman filter and variational data assimilation (DA), and those that seek the understanding of convective storm and tornado dynamics and of initial condition sensitivity through very-large-ensemble approach, the study on the impacts of special data sources. Extension will also be made to study hurricane track and intensity forecasts and their sensitivity to initial and boundary conditions. The grants that supported the research for which supercomputing time is sought in this proposal are listed in the cover page. As a continuation of the experiments of 2007, CAPS seeks resources to perform realtime storm-scale ensemble prediction with increased sophistication that is supported by LEAD and CSTAR grants, and to produce realtime numerical prediction of thunderstorms assimilating data from the CASA radar network. The latter is essential to fulfill the mission of NSF ERC CASA program. In addition, on-demand forecasts will be performed by LEAD across the Teragrid resources. A combined total of 2,576,200 service units (SUs) across LRAC computing platforms is requested.

PCSE-2016.project_abstract: Class activities for the PCSE 2016 class. About 50 students expected who are going to learn parallel computing.

Electron-properties.project_abstract: In this project, we want calculate the electron properties of some two-dimensional systems by applying semi-classical theory.

TG-MCB140210.name: TG-MCB140210
TG-MCB140210.project_abstract: This new proposal requests computational resource to support two projects in the Chen lab at Kansas State University. Project 1 aims to combine experiment and simulation to characterize the structural details of a novel class of self-assembling branched amphiphilic peptide capsules (BAPCs) and to rationally design novel sequences with modified BAPC properties. Earlier development of BAPCs has been funded by NIH R01 GM074096 (2010-14), and a new R01 application for continual NIH funding is currently pending. Project 2 aims to understand the mechanism of molecular mechanism for facile binding of BH3-only protein Bim to the pro-survival protein Bcl-w using a combination of molecular modeling and kinetic and thermodynamic experiments, which is currently supported by a CAREER award from NSF, MCB 0952514 (2010-15).

TG-CTS130005.name: TG-CTS130005
TG-CTS130005.project_abstract:
The Rayleigh-Taylor instability (RTI), a process by which the misalignment of the pressure and the density gradient at unstably stratified interfaces generates baroclinic vorticity, can transition a laminar flow field to a fully mixed turbulent field. The RTI occurs in a wide variety of atmospheric, oceanic, geophysical and astrophysical flows and, despite recent progress made through numerical simulations, remains poorly understood, e.g., the late-time turbulent multi-material mixing behavior for multimode initial conditions. The key difficulty is that the long transient of this initially laminar flow, i.e., turbulence is achieved only at late times. Furthermore, many numerical methods are based on the concept of implicit large-eddy simulation, where large scales are resolved but the small-scale dynamics are modeled purely using the numerical dissipation. Although successful in representing the large-scale behavior, it is far from clear that the energy dissipation and mixing processes at the small scales are accurately represented.

The objective of the proposed research is to investigate the late-time turbulence and mixing in the Rayleigh-Taylor instability, with relevance to astrophysics. To achieve this objective, we propose to conduct direct numerical simulation (DNS) using non-dissipative methods, such that all the physics are resolved on the computational grid, and that the numerics no longer affect the solution. This will be achieved with a high-order accurate minimally dissipative kinetic-energy preserving and interface capturing scheme will be used. For this purpose, we request 2.5M SUs to perform a series of RTI simulations as detailed in the proposal. The XSEDE allocation will allow us to perform simulations at sufficiently high Reynolds numbers that the mixing transition is achieved. Our three-dimensional code uses the message-passing interface (MPI) for parallelization and HDF5 library for parallel I/O. High efficiency has been obtained for weak and strong scaling analysis conducted on Ranger and Lonestar up to 2048 cores.

The present hypothesis is that, by perturbing the interface using an existing turbulent velocity field to mimic multimode initialization, evolution to turbulence and higher Reynolds numbers can be achieved more rapidly. By solving the full compressible Navier-Stokes equations, we will quantify isotropy and intermittency of the decaying turbulence (i) first without gravity, (ii) then with a gravitational field. In the latter, we will make the region of initial turbulence larger to determine how turbulence ahead of the mixing region influences the instability growth. Through resolved calculations, we will be able to determine the mechanisms that govern the mixing.  We expect that the results will depend on a ratio of time scale describing the turbulence decay to that of the Rayleigh-Taylor instability.  Preliminary low-resolution results using our start-up allocation shows that, surprisingly, the initial growth rates of bubble and spikes decrease in the presence of an isotropic velocity field in front of them.

A-ch6.name: A-ch6
A-ch6.project_abstract:
This research project focuses on the development of a hybrid, multiscale simulation approach to predict the equilibrium and dynamical properties of polymer nanocomposites. Polymer nanocomposites are materials synthesized by the addition of a small weight fraction of anisotropic filler particles to polymeric matrices. There has been a recent surge of interest in these materials due to their unique materials properties such as modulus, fire retardency gas permeability and rheology. Many of these property enhancements are quite uncharacteristic of what one might expect in the addition of such small amounts of fillers to polymeric matrices. Consequently, an unresolved and an active area of current research is to try and unearth the fundamental mechanisms by which such fillers impact upon the structure and properties of polymers.  

We have undertaken a computational approach to address the above question. But, this approach is by no means trivial. On the one hand, the filler particles are highly anisotropic and has atleast one dimension of nanometers. On the other hand, the polymers need to be modeled at the scale of monomers which are in Angstroms. These disparate length scales suggest the development of a multiscale simulation approach. We have developed a preliminary version of a multiscale approach that combines the molecular dynamics simulation for the particles with a coarse-grained approach termed as dissipative particle dynamics for the polymers. This effectively addresses the above issues, and can potentially be used to map out the mechanistic details of the polymer nanocomposite system.

Despite the use of a multiscale simulation idea, the simulations necessitate extensive computational resources to get rid of system size effects and also to obtain good statistical sampling for the dynamical simulations. Currently, our research group resources have around 20 workstations which are shared between this project and two other computationally intensive projects. We are requesting these resources on TACC to enable fruition of this high impact project. This research also impact indirectly upon many experimental groups at UT Austin who are actively pursuing the synthesis and applications of polymeric nanocomposites. Those researches can also be expected to benefit from expedited results that can suggest rational strategies for designing such materials.

TG-CTS130002.name: TG-CTS130002
TG-CTS130002.project_abstract: We request resources from XSEDE to perform large scale simulations for shock wave/turbulent boundary layer interactions (SWTBLI) using direct numerical simulation (DNS) and large eddy simulation (LES) methods. The proposed projects are (1) DNS of SWTBLI at high Mach number and various shock intensities and, (2) LES of three-dimensional effects of lateral walls on SWTBLI. We were awarded a startup allocation to benchmark the performance of our code and determine its scalability. We have established the scalability of our code on TACC Ranger. In addition to performing scaling tests for our code, we have also performed some benchmarking tests for the proposed projects. This enabled us to exactly determine the amount of SUs needed for the completion of each project. Using the results from our benchmarking tests, we have established that we need a total of 1,168,640 SUs for the completion of proposed projects.

SiC-SiO2-Interface.name: SiC-SiO2-Interface
SiC-SiO2-Interface.project_abstract:
SiC|SiO2 interfaces are very important in solid-state research. Their electronic properties are a focus in semi-conductor research of new high-speed electronic devices. Mechanical properties of such interfaces are studied whenever SiC fibers are used in ceramic matrix composite materials.
While understanding is sought, the interface structures are not simple, however. SiC has no native oxide. Instead it will decompose into SiO2 and "carbon" upon oxidation. Problematic in electronic materials is that not all carbon is removed through carbon monoxide during processing, leaving carbon at the interface behind. Such defects trap electron during transport through the devise and cause noise and failure. In mechanical applications, such "graphitic" segregation may deteriorate mechanical properties – or may be fortuitous since it retards further oxidation.
We will study different SiC|SiO2 interfaces using density functional calculations combined with structure modeling. We first study sharp interface structures between SiC surfaces and SiO2. We will then incorporate additional "C" along the interface, ranging from glassy SiCO structures to chunks of C segregated at the interface.
Our focus are the change in electronic properties on one side, and the change in adhesion, interfacial energy, and strength of the interface at the other side.

P-UTA2.name: P-UTA2
P-UTA2.project_abstract:
The study of the electronic and geometric properties of surfaces are particularly important for systems like the actinides which are characterized by a gradual filling of the 5f-electron shell with the degree of localization increasing with the atomic number Z. The open shell of the 5f electrons determines the magnetic and solid state properties of the actinide elements and their compounds and understanding the quantum mechanics of the 5f electrons is the defining issue in the chemistry and physics of actinide elements. These elements are also characterized by the increasing prominence of relativistic effects and their studies can, in fact, help us understand the role of relativity throughout the periodic table. 
In this work, we thus propose to carry out electronic structure calculations for uranium U, plutonium Pu, and americium Am surfaces, and molecular adsorptions on such. The eventual goal is a complete understanding of the surface chemistry and physics processes of all actinide surfaces. Central questions relate to the electronic structure, localization of the 5f electrons and the magnetism of the actinide elements. The change from metallic 5f bonding into local-moment nonbonding configurations that takes place between Pu and Am is rather unique in the periodic table and is at the very heart of our understanding of electronic structure. Considering the narrow bandwidth of surface states, any transition from itinerant to localized behavior first takes place at the actinide surfaces. The second approach to study these surfaces will be through atomic and molecular adsorption studies on a series of carefully selected actinide substrates. We note that studies of the reactions of the actinides with atomic and molecular systems are critically important for environmental reasons. Our proposed studies might also guide us towards a safe disposition of actinide elements like plutonium when necessary.

TG-AST120025.name: TG-AST120025
TG-AST120025.project_abstract:
We request computing time on the XSEDE resources to perform high-resolution, cosmological simulations of galaxy formation which will resolve the interstellar medium (ISM) physics with un- precedented realism. In our new physical model, the ISM is explicitly resolved into dense molecular clouds. Star formation is confined to these high-density regions and, as it proceeds, injects large quantities of energy and momentum into the surrounding medium via stellar feedback. This stellar feedback is critical to produce realistic galaxies and to generate powerful galactic winds. These galactic winds also have important effects on the circum-galactic and intergalactic media (CGM, IGM), and understanding them is a key frontier.
For the first time, we incorporate all the important stellar feedback mechanisms (radiation pressure in the ultra-violet, optical, and infrared; stellar winds; supernova explosions of Types I & II; and photoionization heating in HII regions) in a self-consistent manner. The combination of resolved, clumpy ISM and positive reinforcement of different feedback mechanisms produce powerful galactic winds with properties consistent with observations without ad hoc prescriptions, which previous simulations typically have had to incorporate.
For this initial study, our proposed simulations concentrate on the high-redshift Universe. This regime, of intense observational focus, is less computational expensive and will therefore allow us to simulate a range of galaxies (from dwarfs to massive disks) to develop a systematic understanding of the scale-dependent physics.
Thanks to their novelty and realism, the proposed set of simulations will be analyzed to address a wide array of timely scientific questions. We will study the evolution of the galactic ISM, galaxy growth and its self-regulation via galactic winds, the interaction of infalling material with galactic outflows, metal dispersion in the CGM and IGM, as well as the thermal, kinematic, and ionizing effects of galaxies on their surroundings. XSEDE resources provide the computational power necessary to perform our simulations, which have outgrown our local computing resources. We will use the well-tested smooth particle hydrodynamics (SPH) code Gadget-3, which we significantly expanded to implement more realistic cooling, star formation, and feedback modules (also verified in a series of recent papers describing them).
We have successfully performed multiple medium-sized runs using the production version of the code on a university-based computing cluster and have successfully compiled and run basic scaling tests with the same version of the code on Ranger at TACC. This enabled us to estimate runtime requirements for our proposed simulations, totaling 1.76 million SUs.

TG-ATM140018.name: TG-ATM140018
TG-ATM140018.project_abstract: The Sahel is a diverse climatic region that includes a semi-arid tropical zone in the north and a humid tropical climate zone to the south. Understanding Sahelian climate seasonal, interannual, and decadal variability and anomaly has been recognized as a critical component in global climate studies by international programs, such as CLIVAR, GEWEX, and AMMA.  The more severe drought in the last century in the world, strong coupling between Sahel climate and external forcings, the controversy on the causes of the Sahel climate anomalies, especially the drought, and its significant social and economic implications make this region extremely important for the scientific community.   This project will contribute to identification of the attribution of Sahel rainfall changes to anthropogenic and natural drivers, and the effect of climate variability on its ecosystems and water resources

TG-CHE130008.name: TG-CHE130008
TG-CHE130008.project_abstract: Solar energy is one of the most promising renewable sources to dissolve the pressing worldwide energy crisis, which is caused by our dominant reliance on the environmentally unfriendly fossil fuels. Owing to the explosion in computational power over the last decade, the computational modeling of the critical yet experimentally unobservable photon-electron exchange has become feasible on realistic time scales and length scales. In the proposed projects, we will apply several novel time-dependent optical theories to study the light-matter interactions in a wide variety of photo-voltaic, photo-catalytic and photo-conductive devices, including plasmon-enhanced dye-sensitized solar cells, singlet fission polycrystalline and photo-modulable molecular wire.

TG-EAR150001.name: TG-EAR150001
TG-EAR150001.project_abstract: Mantle plume theory suggests that thermal upwellings from the deep mantle are the cause of hotspot volcanism, and are responsible for some of the largest eruptions in Earth's history. Geophysicists have long been searching for seismological evidence of plumes, but there still remains a lack of consensus as to their existence . Tomographic images of the mantle beneath several hot spots have shown low velocity regions that may be attributable to mantle plumes. This interpretation however, remains controversial since it is unclear whether deep mantle plumes impart observable travel time delays to body waves, or whether delays will be erased due to wavefront healing. Here we will combine geodynamic modeling of mantle plumes with 3D synthetic seismic waveform modeling in order to quantitatively determine the conditions under which mantle plumes should be seismically visible.

TG-MCA08X012.name: TG-MCA08X012
TG-MCA08X012.project_abstract:
Chip design faces a crisis  the 40 year process of transistor downscaling has led to atomic-scale features, making devices subject to unavoidable manufacturing irregularities at the atomic scale and to heat densities comparable to a nuclear reactor. A new approach to design that embraces the atomistic, quantum mechanical nature of the constituent materials is necessary to develop more powerful yet energy miserly devices. 

Electronic device engineering and material science must meet at the atomic scale to design new switching concepts. This demands the solution of quantum non-equilibrium statistical mechanics in systems in excess of 107 complex degrees of freedom. Computations of this magnitude have been impossible, due to the lack of sufficiently powerful computers. Petascale computing creates an opportunity to pursue a multi-scale design approach that fuses nano scale (atomic) to the macro scale (wire), which will make possible new kinds of device designs that were previously unimaginable. We propose to develop a general-purpose simulation engine. It will model out-of-equilibrium electron transport in realistically extended devices using fully quantum mechanical (QM) models in an atomistic material description containing millions of atoms. Using this new approach, designers can directly address questions of quantization and spin, tunneling, phonon interactions, and heat generation. 

It is widely accepted that the Non-Equilibrium Green Function Formalism (NEGF) QM statistical mechanics theory, in conjunction with an atomistic basis, can answer these questions. It is also widely perceived that the problem is too hard to solve. The PI Klimeck developed NEMO 1-D, the first NEGF-based commercial-grade device simulator, and NEMO 3-D, which calculates electronic structure (no NEGF) for systems larger than 52 million atoms. The codes have been shown to scale to more than 23,000 / 8,192 cores, respectively, on TOP500 machine numbers 2, 7, 8, 30, and 46. We propose to extend the NEGF capabilities of NEMO 1-D with the NEMO 3-D electronic structure description to form the next generation device and materials engineering toolkit OMEN. The necessary levels of parallelism to tackle the problem on 200,000+ CPUs have been designed and demonstrated to scale well. Computer scientists and HPC experts embedded in the team will guide the implementation and explore performance, execution reliability, and alternative hardware and algorithms. 

This research and development has been funded through a PetaApps award by NSF. This proposal highlights the scaling results we currently have available and indicates why we are requesting a large resource allocation from the TeraGrid.

TG-ENG150008.name: TG-ENG150008
TG-ENG150008.project_abstract: The requested allocation will be used for 30 students enrolled in a senior-level course at the University of Michigan, College of Engineering, Department of Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering. The course title is "Introduction to Numerical Hydrodynamics", NA 423. The students will work on performing simulations of the flow over an Ahmed body using Large-Eddy Simulation. The software that is used in the course is OpenFOAM. It is envisioned that the students will be able to complete their projects using 60 processes in approximately 55 hours. With 30 students an allocation of 100,000 cpu-hrs is requested.

FDTD3D-Cont.name: FDTD3D-Cont
FDTD3D-Cont.project_abstract:
In now-completed projects (FDTD3D, TG-DMS080033N), the PI conducted large-scale tests of the IWAVE simulation package. This package has been used to benchmark synthetic data for the SEAM project, a multicompany oil industry consortium. The SEAM data will be made available for use by the entire geophysical research community; it is considerably larger (and closer to contemporary field data dimensions) and has much greater physical fidelity than prior benchmark data sets. Our role was to verify its accuracy. In the course of our work with SEAM, considerably assisted by the projects at TACC, my group (re)discovered significant flaws in the standard simulation technology (regular grid finite difference methods) and began working to overcome these deficiencies. Iwave itself, while quite conservative, represents the first public domain seismic simulator with high-order stencils, efficient absorbing boundary conditions, and both message-passing and thread--based parallelism demonstrated to scale well to hundreds of cores. Iwave will be released at the upcoming SEG meeting and published by the SEG.

The current request asks for sufficient resources to carry on the prior work in several directions:

(1) together with several students, I have developed an object-oriented wrapper around Iwave to produce the various components of data-fitting model estimation (known as full waveform inversion in reflection seismology) along with several other techniques in imaging (reverse time migration) and novel inversion methods (nonlinear velocity analysis). These applications require testing at a scale not available in my lab.

(2) the spin-off project to enhance simulation accuracy fhrough efficient structured-mesh finite element modeling has achieved its goal in one case already, namely constant density acoustics (to be presented fpr the first time at the SEG 2009 meeting). The main feature is the necessity of capturing subgrid features in the model in upscaled stiffness and mass matrix coefficients. I have proposed a method for upscaling in teh special case of constant density acoustics which requires the coefficient field to be represented by spatial multiresolution (wavelet expansion). This representation dovetails with inversion methodology - if successful it will alter the way in which models are constructed in this field. Once again, large scale tests are a necessity for this new application of Iwave.

(3) both as part of my own research program and to support Phase II of the SEAM project, I have begun to construct an elastic modeling capability within the Iwave framework. The computational complexity is an order of magnitude greater than acoustics, and large-scale testing will be necessary earlier in the process.

TG-MCB150053.name: TG-MCB150053
TG-MCB150053.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB150053.project_abstract: This proposal requests 50,000 SUs for molecular dynamics (MD) simulations on the packaging of the double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome into bacteriophages. During viral assembly, DNA is driven into a pre-formed protein shell (the capsid) against substantial forces by motor proteins that convert the chemical energy of ATP hydrolysis into the mechanical energy of motion. At present, it is not known how the viral motor uses the energy of ATP hydrolysis to generate force. We have recently proposed that DNA is not a passive substrate, but that DNA packaging is driven by forces generated within the DNA itself (the "scrunchworm hypothesis"). The proposed MD simulations will complement experimental tests of the scrunchworm hypothesis.

TG-CHE150058.name: TG-CHE150058
TG-CHE150058.project_abstract:
Biodegradable materials are environmentally friendly alternatives to petroleum-derived polymers such as polyolefins.  While many biodegradable polymers have been developed, the properties of current materials are not controlled at a level comparable to that of olefinic polymers. The present proposal will fill this gap by developing new catalyst systems capable of the controlled copolymerization of monomers with different properties. Catalytic control in these systems will be achieved by switching the redox state of the catalyst between two states with complementary properties. 
Computational methods would have greatly contributed to the development and understanding of molecular chemistry, especially in the field of organometallic chemistry. Theoretical calculations could provide insight into both the electronic structure and the reactivity of transition metal, and, recently, lanthanide and actinide complexes. Theoretical calculations can be employed in conjunction with experiments to propose models for possible mechanisms of a catalytic cycle. Comparison of different mechanisms (i.e., the activation barriers and thermodynamic parameters) permits the exclusion of unfavorable pathways. The examination of the mechanism of a given catalytic cycle by a joint theoretical and experimental approach is helpful in identifying the rate determining step of the catalytic process.

Galois.name: Galois
Galois.field_of_science: COMPUTER AND INFORMATION SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING (CISE)
Galois.project_abstract:
Until recently, most applications that required extreme-scale parallel computing
were concerned with simulations of physical systems, many of which are matrix computation based. However, new problem domains are giving rise to applications with very different algorithmic foundations: they require time-consuming computations on large graphs with millions of nodes. Complex
graph problems arise, for example, in computational biology (e.g., protein classification and modeling studies often build homology graphs in which nodes represent proteins and weighted edges represent similarity), in graphics and video processing (e.g., the effective graph cuts image segmentation algorithm
is based on max-flow computations in a graph), and even in traditional finite-element applications (e.g., the meshes are often expressed as graphs in which the nodes represent triangles or tetrahedra and the edges represent adjacencies).

The Galois project is building a system that exploits optimistic parallelization to execute these kinds of applications in parallel. The programming model is sequential Java augmented with two constructs called optimistic set iterators. Results from a first-cut shared-memory implementation of Galois on small-scale multicore processors are promising. Therefore, we would like to study scalability of the Galois system on a large-scale shared-memory system like Maverick.

TG-DMR140131.name: TG-DMR140131
TG-DMR140131.project_abstract: The creation of less expensive catalyst materials with selective oxidation of natural gas to liquid fuels conversion with mild reaction condition, a central research subject in modern chemistry, is a major challenge.  Our hypothesis is that graphene can be functionalized with transition metal based functional groups and these functional groups could aid in the catalysis of oxidative reactions of hydrocarbons and convert it into liquid fuels.  In this work, we will develop a graphene based catalyst materials, i.e. graphene functionalized with transition metal phthalocyanine (TMPc) and make a Graphene-TMPc active catalyst materials.  Technically, graphene surface could also play an important role on catalytic activity of TMPc surface by donating/backdonating necessary electrons from/to the graphene substrate and can create additional active sites on the functional groups during hydrocarbon oxidation reaction.  The goal of the proposed research is to develop a fundamental understanding of catalytic oxidation reaction of methane, a major fraction of natural gas components, to methanol conversion process.  All results will be modeled with ab initio density functional theory (DFT) to develop an understanding of functionalization, reaction energetics, and reaction mechanism at the atomic level.  Finally, we will assess the viability of this proposed material for efficient single step reaction of gaseous methane to liquid fuel conversion process by evaluating the kinetic properties of overall oxidation reaction.  This material will not only have low cost but also have significant advantages over conventional catalysts for the selective oxidation of natural gas to methanol conversion process at mild reaction condition.
TG-DMR140131.pi_institution: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology

TG-MCA07S033.name: TG-MCA07S033
TG-MCA07S033.project_abstract:
We request computer resources through the NRAC program so that we are able to take advantage of the recent developments of the Riverside model of the heliosphere and perform numerical analysis of the solar wind - local interstellar medium interaction with the realistic, based on the available observations, boundary conditions. Such resources are the proper venue for our research because it involves not only high-resolution, shock-capturing, 3D solution of MHD equations on adaptive grids, but also direct simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) modeling of neutral atoms. We propose to advance computational space, astro-, and plasma physics by further developing a new class of computational codes for plasmas and neutral gases that integrates multiple scales and multiple physical processes and descriptions. 
Among these are MHD modeling of plasma, Monte Carlo or multi-fluid modeling of neutral particles, and kinetic modeling of the Galactic cosmic ray transport throughout the heliosphere. The results obtained with our adaptive mesh refinement code will be compared with spacecraft observations and contribute to our understanding the properties of the solar wind plasma and the heliosheath. The code will become publicly available after the end of our science projects.

TG-CHE140139.name: TG-CHE140139
TG-CHE140139.project_abstract: The current proposal seeks new Research allocations of the XSEDE supercomputing resources for the computational studies of the mechanism, reactivity, and selectivity of various transition metal-catalyzed reactions. Our initial computational studies will focus on the understanding of new modes of reactivity in carboncarbon bond activation reactions. We will perform density functional theory (DFT) calculations to elucaite the reaction mechanisms, factors that control reactivity and selectivity, and the steric and electronic effects of ligands. These computational insights will be applied to develop quantitative models to computationally screen and predict new catalytic systems with improved efficiency and selectivity.

TG-DMR070072N.name: TG-DMR070072N
TG-DMR070072N.project_abstract: We propose to apply Teragrid computing resources to investigate oxide and nitride semiconductors, hydrogen storage, and novel CMOS materials. We will apply state-of-art first-principles computational methods based on density functional theory to investigate the atomistic features and the electronic structure of surfaces, interfaces, native defects, and impurities in technologically important oxide and nitride semiconductors, non-classical CMOS materials, and complex hydrides.  Our group has a strong record in the research of wide-band-gap semiconductors, doping and defect physics, semiconductor surfaces and heterojunctions.  There are currently 12 researchers in our group,  including 1 university faculty, 1 project scientist, 1 associate specialist, 4 postdocs, and 5 Ph D students.  Our research is funded by external grants from NSF, DOE, the UCSB Solid State Lighting and Energy Center, the ACS Petroleum Fund and the Semiconductor Research Corporation.  In this proposal we are requesting a total of 1,115,000 Teragrid SUs for the year 2009.

A-ch511.name: A-ch511
A-ch511.project_abstract:
This research work is focus on investigation of the relationship between microstructure and physical properties of the porous materials, such as an oil bearing rock, a piece of paper, or a polymer composite. Discovering the accurate relationship is a long standing problem of theoretical and practical interest in many fields of technology: 1) Build virtual porous materials numerically on the computer. A detailed charateristics of the micriostructure can be obtained; 2) Develop the sophisticated algorithm to simulate the single phase flow through the porous materials, and calculate its transport properties; 3) Develop new algorithm to simulate 
the electrical conducticion of the materials.

TG-MCA93S028.name: TG-MCA93S028
TG-MCA93S028.project_abstract: During 2005/2006 our group published 31 papers [1-31] and eight reviews [32-39] reporting our LRAC supported research. One paper notably described the first all-atom simulation of an entire virus, showing that some virus capsids assemble around preformed RNA; the reviews covered three fields which have become transformed through advanced computing: membrane transport, cellular mechanics, and bionanotechnology.  Over the past 15 years, we have published more than a hundred molecular dynamics studies, which were cited over 3,100 times. The great impact is very much due to our close link between computational work and experimental work: about half of our 2005/2006 papers were co-authored with experimental collaborators.  Through our own simulations, as well as through simulations of others using our groups program NAMD, the power of NSFs high performance computers is being harnessed daily for mainstream life science. This year, again, all studies proposed by us are linked directly to the laboratory bench, each involving a leading experimental investigator. We seek to continue investigating forefront biology (protein gas conduction, virus infection, DNA loop formation by proteins, mechanosensitive membrane channels, transport through nuclear pores, proteins acting as springs) and to add two ambitious, already well advanced, investigations on bacterial flagella and ribosome, projects which demand simulations of millions of atoms on thousand processors. In addition to all-atom approaches, our studies involve coarse-graining methods that reach beyond 10 microseconds simulation periods. The latter methodology is backed up by six successfully completed investigations [16, 27, 40-43] and heralds a new era in computational biology.

TG-MCB140208.name: TG-MCB140208
TG-MCB140208.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB140208.project_abstract:
The highly conserved protein phosphatase-1 (PP1) dephosphorylates proteins in all eukaryotic cells. Inhibitor-2 (I2) is an ancient, abundant, and enigmatic PP1 regulatory protein. I2 inhibits PP1 activity, but the PP1-I2 complex can regain phosphatase activity without dissociation after phosphorylation of Thr74 in a 73-residue I2 unstructured domain. Understanding how phosphorylation within the unstructured I2 domain regulates PP1 function is the major focus of this work. Our preliminary data shows that computer molecular dynamic simulations can recapitulate the early steps of phosphorylation-dependent activation of PP1-I2. Data obtained in a XSEDE startup allocation showed that in silico, explicit solvent, phosphorylation-dependent PP1-I2 activation occurred in complexes with human, worm, and yeast I2 orthologs, despite great sequence variations in these I2 orthologs. 
  Our current request has three foci. First, we will explore mechanistic aspects of how I2 Thr74 phosphorylation communicates to the PP1 active site over 20 angstroms away. We will test five overlapping hypotheses by simulating I2 mutants and by artificially altering the dynamics. Second, we will seek an understanding of why particular PP1 mutant proteins are exquisitely dependent on I2 function in yeast. We anticipate these PP1 mutant proteins recruit I2 for folding assistance because they fold poorly by themselves. Thermal denaturation in silico of wild-type and mutant PP1 proteins will explore this contention. Third, accelerated and constant pH molecular dynamics will seek structures of activated, phosphorylated PP1-I2, which require greater time and potentially protonation-dependent conformation changes.

TG-PHY090031.name: TG-PHY090031
TG-PHY090031.project_abstract: New, efficient and scalable approaches to solving the time-dependent Schroedinger equation are developed and applied to the interaction of laser radiation with atoms, molecules and Bose condensates.  We address three important problems; the interaction of short pulse lasers with He, examining the role of electron correlation in single and double electron ejection; the interaction of laser fields with Bose condensates, as described by the time-dependent non-linear Schreodinger equation to create new topological structures such as persistent currents and Josephson junctions and the generalization of the methodology to many-electron atoms such as Ne and Ar.  All of these problems are being actively studied experimentally and require significant computational resources to make further progress.

-Engaging-and-Target.name: -Engaging-and-Target
-Engaging-and-Target.project_abstract: Emerging mobile technologies such as geofencing have made it possible to track and empirically study the phenomena of mobile targeting. Based on a unique data set on mobile targeting and consumers' behavior, we examine the impact of mobile promotions on foot traffic to shopping malls through a mutually exiciting/inhibitory spatio-temporal point process. Foot traffic to a shopping mall is measured by consumers' visits recorded through geofence technologies while consumer engagement is evaluated with mobile app launches. Consumers may be targeted based on their individual historical behavior (“behavioral targeting”) or on their current locations (“location-based targeting”). We model app launch, shopping mall visit and location-based targeting as “events” which may mutually excite or inhibit each other while behavioral targeting is externally controlled. The exciting or inhibitory effects are location-dependent, which allows us to study how mobile couponing and mobile targeting influence consumers’ shopping mall choices and to investigate the role of location on consumers engagement. Based on our model estimates, we will conduct a series of simulation to provide additional insights on how consumers should be targeted on mobile.

TG-ATM140004.name: TG-ATM140004
TG-ATM140004.project_abstract: There is ample evidence that dynamical models of the Earth's climate system have the potential to make skillful seasonal predictions of the Indian summer monsoon rainfall from May to September. Currently, however, there is still a major gap between the level of predictability and actual prediction skill, which can be attributed to both inadequate model physics and inaccurate initial state. This proposal requests computational resource to improve the seasonal monsoon prediction, using the version 2 of the Climate Forecast System (CFSv2), which is the current operational climate prediction model at the National Centers for Environmental Predictions. We concentrate on improving the ocean initialization of the forecast system, where most of the memory for seasonal predictability resides. For this purpose, we will conduct a set of 28-year (1979-2009) hindcast experiments, using our newly developed strategy of multiple analysis ensemble (MAE) initialization of ocean. It is expected that the MAE strategy will significantly reduce the effect of the inherent uncertainty in current ocean analyses and thus improve the seasonal prediction skill of the sea surface temperature (SST) in not only the tropical eastern Pacific, but also the western Pacific and Indian Oceans, which will further lead to improved Indian Monsoon prediction. A set of the idealized initialization experiments will also be conducted to help evaluate the effects of the model systematic bias. Furthermore, some sensitivity experiments will be conducted to examine the relative contributions to the monsoon prediction by the SST anomalies in the tropical Pacific, Indian and Atlantic basins respectively, as well as the influences of the atmospheric model resolution on the tropical air-sea interaction. The total requested computational allocation for these experiments is 4.30 million core-hours (su) on Stampede.

TG-CCR160001.name: TG-CCR160001
TG-CCR160001.project_abstract:
At Cornell University, Ken Birmans research effort has explored scalable reliability and fault-tolerance on distributed computing platforms, with notable successes.  Technology he and his students created have been used in settings as varied as the French air traffic control system, the New York Stock Exchange floor trading system, the US Navy AEGIS command and control center,  a past version of CERNs software to control their large accelerator ring, Amazons cloud computing infrastructure, Microsofts cluster computing management systems, and the list goes on.  

With students Jonathan Behrens and Sagar Jha, the team now believes it has created two very powerful technologies specifically aimed at the HPC community, the cloud computing community, and other large, scalable computing infrastructures.  

Our reliable data replication tool, RDMC, builds a communication overlay graph using point-to-point RDMA or Infiniband links, then transmits objects reliably from source(s) to destinations.  RDMC scales well: performance with hundreds of replicas is only a very small factor worse than performance with just one or two.  The data rates achieved can be quite close to the full possible speed of the underlying optical network, and in fact RDMC was faster than MPI for a significant range of data transfer sizes and replication levels when we compared our numbers with reported figures for the LLNL deployment of MVAPICH.  Uses for RDMC include making file replicas at extremely high speeds with minimal latency, reliable multicast patterns in which an application generates data and must share it within a cluster of receivers, and capture of data from sensors such as video cameras, which might then need to spray it over a parallel computing application.

A second tool, SST, offers a simple shared state-table.  The model here is very simple: each compute in a cluster has an associated row in a table of N rows.  The columns can be defined by the user and have whatever meaning is desired: load, queue backlogs, convergence precision, round number, etc.  SST allows the application to define predicates over these tables and can automatically compute averages, min, max, and other aggregated values.   When a predicate becomes true, a callback is issued.  For example, it is trivial to code the predicate When all nodes complete round K, call this barrier release method.

RDMC and SST are both open-source libraries coded in C++ and will be released to the general public under standard 3-clause BSD licensing.  

Stampede request: We request a small amount of time on Stampede to port our solution onto your platform (in principle, trivial) and to test it carefully.  We then wish to conduct a series of full experimental runs expected to take about 30 minutes.  These full runs, on 40 nodes each within a single rack, would permit a very detailed style of experimental evaluations, and well probably need to do 5 or 10 of those for each system, since we often fine-tune our code and try again.  But we can do our debugging with very short runs that wouldnt take more than a minute or two each.  Accordingly, we request access to Stampedes login nodes for this type of porting, compilation, and basic debugging, which shouldnt be difficult, after which we would conduct a series of experiments at the scale of approximately 40 nodes, running for no longer than 30 minutes each.

Down the road we might also be interested in trying a larger experiment but at this stage, our hope is to work entirely within a single Stampede rack, with no traffic across the top-of-rack switching network.  This will help us do a very careful evaluation of RDMC and SST when all nodes have full bisection bandwidth and identical latencies.  At LLLN on Infiniband, we were able to test on as many as 512 nodes, but found that the variable latencies and unknown background loads on the switching network made these experiments difficult to understand, so on Stampede, we prefer to take smaller steps, one by one, and get very careful measurements. 

Deliverables:  Upon completion, we will be releasing RDMC and SST through Dave Lifkas Cornell organization and via other public channels.  Well document our code and will provide support for any Stampede users who wish to try it.  We also plan to combine RDMC and SST into a more comprehensive system for fault-tolerance, data replication with strong consistency and scalable computing, and will also release that solution to your community.

We are also working with an HPC community: the so-called "smart grid" community working to improve efficiency of the US Northeastern bulk power grid (our main collaborators are ISO NE, NY ISO and NYPA) and also the large regional distribution networks (our collaborator here is Eaton LLC, as well as teams at CMU and Argonne national labs).  We expect to apply RDMC and SST in these settings.

TG-DMR110058.name: TG-DMR110058
TG-DMR110058.project_abstract: We request an allocation of 2.5 million service units on TeraGrid resources, principally Steele, Lonestar, and KIDS to perform the search for materials, nanoparticles and surfaces with desired properties using hybrid evolutionary approach and phase transition investigation. The structures, properties and phase transition pathway of the solid phases in the Fe-O and Mg-F systems will be studied. The main goal of the project is to predict the phase transition mechanism in Fe-O and Mg-F systems under high pressure and temperature. Central to this project is the PIs USPEX code (including evolutionary algorithm, metadynamics method, the VC-NEB method and TPS approach), interfaced with first-principles electronic structure calculations. This approach has already given many interesting predictions confirmed by experiment. Our calculations will be performed with the widely used ab-initio VASP code. The properties of the stable and metastable structures obtained in this project will be studied and promising new functional materials will be identified. These calculations, in addition to providing practically important results, will also allow us to test the concept of hybrid global optimization, where global optimization with respect to a desired property (for example hardness) is conducted in the space of local minima of the (free) energy. We present VASP scaling measurements on Abe (similar to Steele, Lonestar). Our request of 2.5 million SUs will enable the structural prediction and phase transition pathway investigation in the Fe-O and Mg-F systems.

TG-MCA94P018.name: TG-MCA94P018
TG-MCA94P018.project_abstract:
With both a massively parallel gravity/SPH code and ``embarrassingly
parallel'' dynamical simulations, we will to study problems on vastly
different scales: from the formation of the Oort cloud of comets in
our solar system to the collapse of the largest gravitationally bound
structures in the Universe.  On cosmological scales, we will extend
our previous high resolution simulations of galaxy formation by
focusing on the spiral galaxy scaling relations (e.g. the Tully-Fisher
relation) between galaxy mass, as determined by rotation velocity, and
morphological properties of the galaxy such as disk scale lengths and
bulge to disk ratios.  We will take a multi pronged approach to this
problem.  First we will continue our campaign of high resolution
simulations of individual galaxies in their cosmological context using
a ``zoom-in'' technique.  Our focus here will be trying to understand
the origin of ``bulgeless galaxies'' which we have not been able to
simulate thus far.  Secondly we will perform a simulation of a
cosmological volume at moderate resolution in order to get a fair
sample in order to more directly compare with observational surveys.
Lastly, we will focus particular attention to our Local Group of
galaxies by performing a simulation with initial conditions
constrained by observations of the nearby large scale structure.  This
will be similar to our ``zoomed-in'' galaxies except the focus will be
on Andromeda, the Milky Way and the surrounding structure.

On galactic scales we will continue to study the formation of the
outer regions of disks via interactions with bars and spiral density
waves.  Our emphasis this year will be on including more cosmological
context in these studies.  We will be including local and cosmic UV
background flux, and will be including interactions with other
structure via mergers.  We will also be looking at this phenomenon in
lower mass galaxies.  Our study of the morphological transformation of
disks in clusters will continue by looking at a variety of galaxy
models as they fall into and interact with a galaxy cluster.

On planetary scales, we will study the formation of the Oort cloud as
a function of the galactic environment in of the early Solar System.
Whether the Sun was part of an open cluster in the early stages of
planet formation effects the distribution of the comet cloud, and
thereby determines the frequency and strength of subsequent comet
showers.

We will also be continue performing scaling tests of our recently publicly released parallel N-body code, ChaNGa.

TG-CHE150062.name: TG-CHE150062
TG-CHE150062.project_abstract: Interfacial layers in hybrid solar cells facilitate interface stability and can potentially improve other properties such as solar absorption, charge transfer, and exciton lifetime. In this project, we use density functional theory to study the effect of interfacial modifiers on the photovoltaic properties of a ZnO/P3HT interface. Specifically, we focus on the effect of a CdS monolayer on the solar cell's redox cascade and interfacial charge distribution. We also evaluate the impact of doping ZnO with Sr and N on interfacial properties. Our goal is to identify the source of the experimentally observed photovoltaic enhancement in these systems, thereby predicting future directions for further improvement of hybrid solar cells.

TG-MCA94P017.name: TG-MCA94P017
TG-MCA94P017.project_abstract: An allocation is requested for large scale computer simulations of multiple and single proton transport (PT) in biomolecular systems, coarse-graining, and large multi-scale simulations of biological assemblies. In the case of PT, the interaction of the proton with the biomolecular environment is represented by the multi-state empirical valence bond (MS-EVB) method, and the potential of mean force (PMF) along the pathway of PT is calculated by averaging over highly parallel swarms of trajectories. A novel methodology to simulate multiple protons, based on the MS-EVB, has just been developed by our group and scales nearly linearly with proton number. Large atomistic simulations of biological assemblies will be performed in order to systematically parameterize coarse-grained mesoscopic models that will be employed to examine long time- and length-scale phenomena. Multi-scale coupled simulations of embedded proteins in lipid bilayers, as well as spectrin filaments will be employed to directly examine atomistic-level couplings with mesoscopic phenomena. These studies are extremely challenging and well suited to parallel supercomputing environments.

TG-DMR130046.name: TG-DMR130046
TG-DMR130046.project_abstract: An allocation of 660,000 SU of computing time on Stampede and 5Tb of storage space is requested to support five distinct research projects in the ar- eas of thermal conductivity and energy materials currently being developed by the PIs research group. A startup allocation granted on Ranger and later deployed to Stampede has helped commence four of these research projects, and we now request a research allocation of time and space to further the ongoing projects and expedite the new one. Specifically, the allocation will support three projects on understanding thermal transport processesboth in established energy appli- cations and in new materials in which we seek new ways to control and use heat. The allocation will also support a new collaborative research effort on the devel- opment of a novel graphene-based photovoltaic device. All of these projects will use a combination of classical molecular dynamics simulations and density func- tional electronic structure calculations. These will be performed using established simulation packages that are parallelized and scalable.

Multiscale-Simulatio.name: Multiscale-Simulatio
Multiscale-Simulatio.project_abstract: This basic research effort will develop and validate the first unified discrete Hamiltonian approach to multiscale simulation of reacting shock physics. The methodology developed and validated in this project will demonstrate a fundamentally new approach to multiscale multiphysics modeling.
