It will build on previous shock physics simulation research conducted by the PI, using TACC resources, which was among those featured at the TACC display at Supercomputing 2013.

UQ-Pecos.name: UQ-Pecos
UQ-Pecos.project_abstract: The PECOS center is currently working to perform a variety of model calibrations in various physical domains required for hypersonic re-entry vehicle modeling.  Current efforts are  focused on turbulence, high-temperature kinetics, radiation, and surface ablation.  A Bayesian approach is being applied to perform statistical calibration of uncertain model parameters and these calibrations typically require on the order of 10^5 - 10^6 forward model solves.  Consequently, large processor counts and significant processing time is required to complete the analysis. The resulting joint distributions are used as subsequent input into a coupled, multi-physics full-system analysis.

TG-MCB150109.name: TG-MCB150109
TG-MCB150109.project_abstract:
Recently, nano-bio interfaces have been the subject of significant research in both academic as well as industrial laboratories worldwide due to wide range applications in bio-sensing devices as well as drug delivery. Nanoconjugates with cells, organelles, and intracellular structures containing DNA, RNA, and proteins establish sequences of nano-bio boundaries that depend on several intricate complex bio physicochemical reactions. Given the complexity of these interactions, and their import in governing life at the molecular level, it is extremely important to understand such nanoparticle: biomaterial association. The ultimate success of the bio sensing devices critically depends on the understating and manipulation of complex nano-bio interaction at molecular level. In essence, a complete understanding of nano-bio interaction depends on deeper insights into the science of their complex structure. The overall goal of the proposed research is to understand interaction between biotic and abiotic materials at the molecular level. Our recent investigation on nano-bio interaction enable us to (1) fabricate nano-bio interfaces in control ways; (2) characterize the interfaces in details using several experimental techniques including Raman spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy[1]. To understand the dynamics of the chemical bonding at the interface of the nano-conjugates, we propose to theoretically evaluate the chemical interaction using Quantum Mechanics (QM)-Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations. The essential identification of local bonding configurations due to the intermolecular interactions can be directly compared to the results from density functional theory (DFT) calculations and MD simulations. The fundamental understanding of the interactions will promote to develop advanced bio-sensing and other device applications for various government's research agencies as well as others.

1. A. Bhaumik, A. M. Shearin, R. DeLong, A. K. Wanekaya, K. Ghosh, Probing the interaction at the Nano-Bio Interface using Raman Spectroscopy: ZnO nanoparticles and adenosine triphosphate biomolecules, J. Phys. Chem. C, 118 (32), 18631-18639. 2014.

TG-OCE140024.name: TG-OCE140024
TG-OCE140024.project_abstract:
The NSF Science & Technology Center for Coastal Margin Observation & Prediction (CMOP) is studying the Columbia River estuary as a river-dominated bioreactor, where biogeochemical transformations occur disproportionately through specialized biological hotspots (e.g., lateral bays, estuarine turbidity maxima, and red water blooms). Anchoring the study is an observation network with high-resolution endurance stations, mobile platforms, and process-oriented campaigns. A family of interdisciplinary models has been developed iteratively, with the benefit of calibration/validation against the CMOP data set, and the frequent scrutiny of process-oriented investigators. These models have been ported to the XSEDE environment (through separate specific allocations to CMOP post-docs and students), and are routinely run there for development, calibration, skill assessment and sensitivity simulations. 
Here, we will use mature versions of these models to provide an integrated view of circulation and sediment dynamics, preparatory of net ecosystem metabolism (NEM) simulations in the estuary. We will also examine the estuarys susceptibility to change. Simulations for the contemporary estuary will typically cover periods over a decade, at high-resolution (time step of 36 seconds, saved every 15 minutes). For one of those years, ten scenarios of globally and locally induced change will also be conducted. 
We will map our simulation results onto a modern estuarine classification system, to characterize the dependence of the estuary on the four prevailing physical regimes in the estuary, which are driven by river flows and tides. We will also characterize major ocean influences (as measured by salinity intrusion) relative to the estuarine regimes and coastal-upwelling regimes. By exploring select scenarios of change, we will characterize the susceptibility of the estuarine regimes to evolving external forcing and bathymetry.
This silico analysis will constitute a major advancement in our iterative understanding of a very complex estuary. The analysis will be limited by the modeling skill, which itself depends on the prevailing forcing and estuarine regimes. An extensive modeling skill assessment will be conducted, whichtogether with a rich and diversity observational data setwill be used to assess strengths and weaknesses of the analysis.

TG-AST130007.name: TG-AST130007
TG-AST130007.project_abstract: We propose to run a set of hydrodynamic cosmological simulations that include a complete treatment of galaxy formation physics together with Self-Interacting Dark Matter (SIDM). With them we will search for a solution to the discrepancy between the observed dark matter central densities in galaxies and galaxy clusters, and those predicted by our standard model of cosmological structure formation. For this we will explore the phenomenological consequences of two qualitatively different classes of solutions: self-interacting dark matter and stellar feedback. Our work will contribute to our understanding on how baryons transform the central structure of dark matter halos, how self-interacting dark matter affects galaxy formation, and what are the resulting central densities of dark matter halos when self-interacting dark matter acts together with baryonic processes. We will provide the best constraints available on how strong can dark matter self-interact, and demonstrate if SIDM is a viable solution to the small scale problems that challenge our standard CDM paradigm.

TG-AST130002.name: TG-AST130002
TG-AST130002.project_abstract:
Our group requests a total of 6.5e6 SUs on the TACC machine Stampede to 
conduct global numerical simulations of astrophysical accretion disks.  
We will use the well-tested magnetohydrodynamic code  Athena to carry out these simulations. 
The project is separated into three parts:

We will carry out global MHD simulations to study dust particle dynamics in turbulent protoplanetary disks using our newly developed particle module in Athena. 
 We will study how dust concentrates in turbulence, which is crucial for planetesimal and planet formation.  This study will also make detailed observational predictions  for current telescopes. 

We will add planets in above simulations to study how planets interact with turbulent disks and dust particles in these disks, which is essential for understanding the survivability and growth of young planets.

We will study accretion disks around the white dwarf in interacting close binary system. By comparing with existing observations over past 20 years, such study will enable us to directly constrain accretion physics. 

We propose to run 5 calculations in total. We have already run low resolution studies to explore 
parameter space, and we request XSEDE resources only to run a small number of resolved models that will elucidate the physics of disks in each regime.
Finally, we request 2.5e3 GB of archival storage on the TACC Ranch system.
To visualize the data, we request 2e4 SUs on the TACC machine Maverick.

Funding for the proposed research will be provided by a NASA Hubble Fellowship (awarded to the PI),
the National Science Foundation (AST-0908269) and Princeton University. The time requested is essential for our proposed research since it is the only time requested from our accretion disk group at Princeton university this year.

TG-MCB150102.name: TG-MCB150102
TG-MCB150102.project_abstract:
Reverse micelles consist of water, oil, and a surfactant at the oil-water interface.  Experimental studies show that the water forms spheroidal droplets of remarkably uniform size at suitable points in the ternary phase diagram.  Our aim is to understand the forces that result in such narrow size distributions.  This information is important because reverse micelles are being used increasingly in experimental work as mimics of intracellular biochemical compartments that are small and crowded, but in which proteins fold.

We have numerous simulations currently running on institutional computer clusters, but they are rather small and their architecture yields fundamentally poor performance (approx 2ns/day).  The simulations are of common form: NAMD with Charmm27 parameters, periodic boundaries, Ewald sums, NPT ensemble, TIP3P water, etc.  We have reached 30 ns for some systems, which appear to be well equilibrated for the last 15 ns.  We are seeking XSEDE resources to produce a series of equilibrated systems of varying size to test various hypotheses about why specific sizes are energetically preferred.

We are requesting 200,000 SU because it may be possible to complete the study we are attempting with that allocation.  If not, it will enable us to calculate the allocation needed for a standard allocation with precision.

TG-MCB100145.name: TG-MCB100145
TG-MCB100145.project_abstract: A new research allocation of 3.4M SU's is requested for the October 2010-September 2011 period on the AQSL (Abe, Queen Bee, Steele, and Lonestar) Teragrid clusters to perform large scale parallel replica exchange molecular dynamics simulations of macromolecular complexes. The research we plan to perform, which is funded by NIH grant GM30580 to RML, addresses forefront biophysical issues concerning basic mechanisms of molecular recognition in biological systems. The software infrastructure we propose to employ is optimized through parallelism at various levels of the calculation and can make efficient use of the hardware configuration of the AQSL Teragrid clusters. This request follows a start-up allocation of 50,000 SU's (no. MCB100089) which allowed us to port the necessary code and perform benchmarking tests.

TG-MCB100146.name: TG-MCB100146
TG-MCB100146.project_abstract:
Mechanical phenomena affect nearly every aspect of cellular biology and function, yet the underlying mechanisms of how mechanical forces and biochemical signals interact is not clearly understood. In this proposal, we request for TeraGrid computational facilities to approach cellular mechanotransduction from a computational viewpoint and shed light on two important sub-cellular phenomena in which the role of mechanical factors are decisive: focal adhesion formation and nucleocytoplasmic transport. Individual molecules are suggested to be molecular mechanosensors at focal adhesions. These molecules alter their binding activity upon exposure to external force. We will investigate the validity of this suggestion and evaluate the mechanisms by which single molecules at focal adhesions could act as molecular mechanosensors. 
While our main focus in this proposal will be investigation of focal adhesion formation, we also aim to shed light on nucleocytoplasmic transport across the nuclear pore complex (NPC) using two different approaches: (1) all atomic simulations and (2) coarse-grained modeling. It is suggested that NPC tpr proteins interact with transport factors crm1 and importin-β/α to facilitate the cargo-complex translocation across the NPC. The alleged hydrophobic binding sites, however, are not determined yet. We suggest a thorough molecular dynamic simulation to find those sites. Results from this project could reveal possible mechanisms for facilitated transport. Taking into account the results of all-atomic simulations, we also will develop a coarse-grained model of the whole structure of the NPC to provide a big picture of nucleocytoplasmic transport and find out the specific role of some important factors in active transport, such as FG-repeat density in the pore, active cargo-FG hydrophobic binding affinity, aspect ratio of active cargo, and existing of competing factors within the pore for FG-repeat binding sites. The 9,900,000 SUs we are requesting will let us proceed with these projects and reveal important aspects of each of them at different scales.

TG-MCA06N060.name: TG-MCA06N060
TG-MCA06N060.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCA06N060.project_abstract:
In this renewal application, we request time to continue our investigation of the mechanism of several membrane transporters and channels using simulation methodologies. Several active transporters that use various source of energy in a living cell for their function will be investigated. Furthermore, we will also continue our research on another membrane associated phenomenon, namely mechanism of membrane binding and activation of blood coagulation factors, which constitutes the most productive project over the past funding period, and a strong collaborative effort between 5 labs at UIUC.  In fact, all of the projects are conducted in close collaboration with leading experimental groups.   All Projects address rather slow processes, thus, requiring long simulations. Furthermore, due to the need of explicit representation of the lipid and water, which play role in the mechanism of transporters, and due to the complexity of the structure, large molecular assemblies need to be simulated. Such calculations can only be carried out with the advanced TeraGrid computational resources. The size and
complexity of the function of these proteins pose a great challenge for computational studies. Over the last funding period, however, we have demonstrated through several published papers reported in the Progress Report, that large scale MD simulations can indeed significantly advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of energy coupling and transport phenomena in these biomolecules. Due to limited space and the need to describe 6 projects, we have delegated the progress and discussion of our preliminary results
completely to the Progress Report. Our extensive use of the allocation over the past funding period is the strongest evidence for the computational demands of such biomolecular systems. We note, however, that we have used the allocated time extremely productively and produced a record number of publications (16; please see Progress Report) over the past funding cycle. We would like to give a general clarification with regard to the length of the proposed simulations, which might be perceived as an "unjustified" aspect. All of the projects address rather slow biomolecular processes (at least on the
order of microsecond). As such, even orders of magnitude longer simulations than those described in this application
can be easily justified from a technical point of view. However, we realize that such processes (e.g., complete transport cycle) cannot be currently described in their entirety, and we can only expect to cover some of the steps involved in such processes. Therefore, in order to provide a justification that will hopefully
be satisfactory, almost in all cases we will base the length of the proposed simulations on our existing benchmarks (mostly published) of the same or comparable systems/phenomena.

Lung-cancer-sequenci.name: Lung-cancer-sequenci
Lung-cancer-sequenci.project_abstract: This project involves with a large amount of sequencing data including whole-exome, genome, and RNA-seq data to perform comprehensive study for lung cancer.
Lung-cancer-sequenci.pi_institution: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

Accelerated-Developm.name: Accelerated-Developm
Accelerated-Developm.project_abstract: Our research involves the integration of sophisticated computational models, at multiple scales, highly advanced materials characterization techniques, and combinatorial and accelerated methods for materials processing and property evaluation with focus on Ti-alloys. High fidelity electronic structure calculations of diffusion processes and phase transformation pathways will underpin and inform the Physics of our higher-length scale models. This NSF funded project proposes a new paradigm of alloy development that will be led by computational modeling, is mechanistically informed and validated by critical experiments involving novel combinatorial methods for materials processing and state-of-the-art characterization techniques.

RCPS14.name: RCPS14
RCPS14.project_abstract:
Functional amphiphilic semiconducting conjugated rod-coil block copolymers have attracted increasing interest for their applications in sustainable energy technologies such as polymer solar cells and batteries. Experimental studies have demonstrated that rod-coil block copolymers form novel supramolecular structures of nanowires in solvent environments. However, the molecular details and self-assembling mechanisms are still unknown. The goal of this project is to investigate rod-coil block polymers’ unique phase behavior under solvent effect so as to rationalize experimental design. The proposed molecular dynamics (MD) simulations will provide important insight into the complex phase driving forces, including microphase separation, anisotropic interactions and the solvent effect. The simulations will also elucidate the mechanisms of polymers self-assembling in the solvents environment. This project requires an exploration of multiple, long MD trajectories for ensembles of millions of atoms under different conditions: different solvents, polymer concentrations and polymer chemistry. In the mean time, drawing on atomistic MD simulations, we will develop polymer coarse-grained model and high efficient lattice simulation to study polymer supramolecular structures under solvent effect at mesoscopic scale.

The simulations will be performed using the software packages of Gromacs, Lammps and our own code. We have carried out preliminary simulations of the systems of 1.2 million atoms in shorter time (less than 100 ns) using atomistic MD simulations. In order to illustrate polymers’ self-assembling in solvent environments at larger time scale and larger dimensions, we are in need of additional computational resources.

A-astro.name: A-astro
A-astro.project_abstract: We will carry out ambitious cosmological simulations of the formation of the first sources of light in the early universe. We will utilize our well-tested massively-parallel combined N-body and smoothed-particle hydrodynamics code GADGET2, modified to include the detailed cooling, chemistry, and radiative transfer in primordial gas, to study the assembly process of the first galaxies, including for the first time a realistic treatment of the star formation process, the radiative and chemical feedback from these stars, the generation of turbulence inside the first galaxies, and the growth of supermassive black holes in their centers. We will derive the observational signature of the first galaxies, to be observed with the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), the successor to the HST, planned for launch in 2013.

PIV_Errors.name: PIV_Errors
PIV_Errors.project_abstract: This project will utilize high fidelity computational fluid dynamics (CFD) calculations to generate synthetic experimental data. This database will then be used to understand errors in laser-based flow diagnostics. The CFD data will be generated using the UTcomp multipurpose CFD code developed by Prof. Raman's group. The focus here is on experiments designed to study shock-turbulence interactions in canonical flow configurations. The UTcomp code is highly scalable and has been demonstrated to be efficient on 1024-2048 processors for problem sizes being considered here. The computational time will enable a range of flow conditions to be generated, which will help understand experimental measurement errors in challenging flow conditions. The postprocessing the database to generate the synthetic images and analysis of the flow volume will be carried out on TACC systems as well as local clusters available to us.
PIV_Errors.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-DMR970008S.name: TG-DMR970008S
TG-DMR970008S.project_abstract: Our group studies the structural, thermodynamic, kinetic, electronic, and electrochemical properties of materials for energy technologies with a focus on the ab initio prediction for complex materials. Using our grant from last year, we accomplished most of what we outlined as a plan of research in last year's proposal, and submitted several papers based on that work: 1) we have determined the equilibrium particle shapes for olivine structure LiFePO4 and LiMnPO4 and calculated the energy barriers for lithium in the bulk region to diffuse out at the (010) surface. These factors control the morphology and performance of this important class of Li ion battery cathode materials. 2) We have calculated the bending strain energy, defect energy and interfacial energy in TiS2 nanotubes, and determined the optimal bending angle. These calculations permit a better understanding of the structure of inorganic nanotubes, which is crucial to accurate calculations of their electrochemical and other properties for Li ion battery applications. 3) We constructed the Pourbaix diagrams for both bulk and 0.5 to 2 nm diameter Pt nanoparticles, which helps us understand and improve the stability of Pt nanocatalysts. 4) We developed a method based on the cluster expansion formalism that makes highly accurate thermodynamic calculations of nano-structured materials computationally feasible, and applied it successfully to our test system of Au-Pd nanoparticles to predict ground state structures. This method allows us to extend our computational work to alloyed nanoparticles that are too large for the fully ab initio approach. We are requesting an allocation to allow us to advance our studies on several areas: in Li ion battery materials we will 1) continue the study of LiFePO4 nanoparticles with adsorbates to study how the equilibrium particle morphology is modified by different solution environments and predict optimal synthesis conditions, and 2) study lithiation reactions in alloyed metallic and oxide nanoparticles. 3) In fuel cell catalysis we will investigate the effects of alloying on Pt catalysts. 4) We will also evaluate different quantum mechanical, continuum and hybrid model in the study of electrochemical properties of room temperature ionic liquids for electrolyte and other applications. 5) We will evaluate the optical and transport properties of candidate materials for photovoltaic applications using the GW approximation. The amount of units we are requesting this year is higher than last year's allocation because of the fact that we are expanding our research program to include additional areas of energy technologies and also because of the increased complexity in our calculations.

TG-OCE110011.name: TG-OCE110011
TG-OCE110011.project_abstract: This three year plan for research focuses on the dynamics of oceanic double-diffusive convection, an important small-scale mixing process driven by the two orders of magnitude difference in diffusivities of heat and salt in seawater. The significance of double-diffusive mixing for water-mass transformation and determining the structure of the temperature-salinity relationship in all oceans has become increasingly clear over the last few years. One of the most intriguing aspects of double-diffusive convection is related to its ability to transform smooth vertical gradients into stepped structures consisting of mixed layers separated by thin, stratified interfaces. Recent field data from the tropical Atlantic has shown that vertical fluxes due to salt fingers, within thermohaline staircases, are significantly (by an order of magnitude) enhanced when compared to non-staircase regions with similar stratifications. Thus, it is vital to improve our understanding of thermohaline staircase formation, evolution and large-scale consequences. Double-diffusive mixing plays a fundamental role in the oceans ability to transport and sequester heat, salt, nutrients, pollutants and carbon dioxide. Yet, this small-scale process is not included in most large-scale oceanographic models, including operational Navy models, which severely limits their predictive capabilities. This research plan is aimed at quantifying the double-diffusive transport in both smooth gradients and thermohaline staircases, developing clear insight into the origin of staircases and specifying conditions for their formation. The proposed study will involve numerical process modeling using a pseudo-spectral code, which integrates the Navier-Stokes equations of motion (Boussinesq approximation). Inferences from the model runs will be used to interpret the oceanic fine- and microstructure data and the results of laboratory experiments. Advanced support is requested for collaboration with Dr. Gabriele Jost, who is familiar with the double-diffusive codes and has collaborated with the NPS computational fluid dynamics group in the past. This collaboration involves application of the advanced numerical methods to Double-Diffusion problems. The goal of this collaboration is to perform a series of Direct Numerical Simulations that will form the basis of a parameterization scheme for the General Circulation Models (GCMs). Prof Radko has developed code of his own to solve DDC problems for 2D (SF2D) and 3D (SF3D) problems. The parallelization in these codes is based on OpenMP. In order to handle realistic problem sizes, more computational power is needed than what the current OpenMP version delivers on general multi-core node clusters. SF3D lends itself to MPI parallelization. The 2D version (SF2D) may be a good candidate for running on GPGPU based nodes. Special support is requested for the port of SF2D to a GPGPU system, the development of an MPI based version of SF3D and for the evaluation of existing MPI-based codes and their suitability to the current project.

TG-AST150018.name: TG-AST150018
TG-AST150018.project_abstract:
We propose to use a radiation transfer-hydro code to model the response of a very massive star (VMS) to giant eruption with a high mass loss (Supernova Impostor). These simulations will allow to directly probe a giant eruption for the first time, and to answer the following understand what governs the recovery time from an eruption, what physical processes are involved, and on which time-scales. We will explore how sensitive it is to the amount of mass lost from the VMS in the eruption, the effects of stellar rotation, and try to answer why eruptions in VMS tend to reoccur after a few years.
After successfully simulating an eruption in 1D we propose to explore multidimensional effects that are not present in 1D: convection and mixing, rotation, turbulence, hydro instabilities, meridional currents, tides, and especially multi-dimensional pulsation. These effects are known to affect considerably the stellar properties. It is expected that they will have a significant effect on how a VMS recovers from an eruption.
The code we use is the FLASH code. The code is well-tested and is routinely used and improved by dozens of Astrophysicist. The code was modified to perform the present tasks, and was configured to efficiently run on Stampede.

MINOS.name: MINOS
MINOS.project_abstract: MINOS is a neutrino experiment at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab) which studies neutrino oscillations. The international multi-institutional MINOS Collaboration uses a high intensity Main Injector proton beam to produce neutrinos and two detectors separated by 734 km to measure neutrino mixing parameters. The modeling of the beam and detectors as well as data analysis of events already collected by MINOS over the last three years requires large amounts of computing, data filtration and analysis, and temporary as well as archival storage. Our Texas group is one of the lead institutions on MINOS. We propose to conduct a portion or if possible majority of computing operations for MINOS on TACC and/or TeraGRID under Texas leadership.

TG-MCB130172.name: TG-MCB130172
TG-MCB130172.project_abstract: The Rosetta molecular modeling software package provides experimentally tested and rapidly evolving tools for the 3D structure prediction and high-resolution design of proteins, nucleic acids, and a growing number of non-natural polymers. Despite its free availability to academic users and improving documentation, use of Rosetta has largely remained confined to developers and their immediate collaborators due to the codes difficulty of use, the requirement for large computational resources, and the unavailability of servers for most of the Rosetta applications.  We recently developed a unified web framework for Rosetta applications called ROSIE (Rosetta Online Server that Includes Everyone, http://rosie.rosettacommons.org). ROSIE currently provides access to nine ROSIE applications by six separate developer teams: Docking, RNA de novo, ERRASER, Antibody, Sequence Tolerance, Supercharge, Beta peptide design, NCBB design, and VIP redesign. In the six months since the official ROSIE launch, it has completed over 2,700 jobs for 1,100 users, straining our in-house computer resources.  In this proposal, we request an allocation of computer time on Stampede for use as a back-end computing resource for the public scientific community to access Rosetta biomolecular modeling and design protocols.  The PI recently completed a sabbatical at the University of Texas at Austin, where he worked with staff at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) to plan this endeavor and begin implementation.

BTV.name: BTV
BTV.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
BTV.project_abstract: BTV stands for bluetongue virus. Bluetongue is a disease of livestock: mortality in sheep herds can be in excess of 70%. We are investigating the virus' 3D structure using cryo-electron microscopy. This is a collaboration project with Prof. Polly Roy at Department of Infectious & Tropical Diseases, London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, UK. Prof. Roy provides us the sample. We are responsible for imaging and processing.
BTV.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

TG-MCB130177.name: TG-MCB130177
TG-MCB130177.project_abstract: A fundamental problem in computational biophysics is to deduce the function of a protein from the structure.  Many biological macromolecules such as enzymes, molecular motors, or membrane transport proteins perform their function by cycling between multiple conformational states and thus understanding conformational transitions is central to understanding protein function. The present proposal focuses on two problems in biophysics that require a detailed and quantitative description of macromolecular conformational changes: (1) Understanding the molecular mechanism of sodium/proton exchange by membrane transport proteins, and (2) making progress towards predicting experimentally measurable rates for processes that involve large conformational transitions. In both cases, a detailed understanding of the interactions between protein and environment is required and thus molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are employed.

A-ph911.name: A-ph911
A-ph911.project_abstract: Transition Metal Oxides (TMO) are insulating materials in which electron-electron interactions are especially important.  This makes them interesting theoretically, and different from normal insulators or semiconductors.  We are interested if it is possible to engineer the properties of these materials in the same way that semiconductors have been engineered.  Toy models suggest that gap engineering is possible with the right choice of material parameters.  We are now interested in perorming more realistic, first-principles calculations of TMO heterostructures to explore these ideas further and motivate experimental work.

hp_borehole.name: hp_borehole
hp_borehole.project_abstract:
Authors:
Dr Pawel J. Matuszyk (pawel@ices.utexas.edu)
Prof. Carlos Torres-Verdin (cverdin@uts.cc.utexas.edu)
Prof. Leszek Demkowicz (leszek@ices.utexas.edu)

Abstract:

Acoustic logging is an important component of the non-invasive, in-situ assessment of rock-formation properties in borehole geophysical applications. The numerical modeling  of problems arising in borehole acoustic logging is of great importance for advancing fundamental knowledge of borehole acoustics and for the improvement of acoustic logging techniques used by oil- and oil-service companies to detect and quantify hydrocarbon-bearing rocks. Moreover, the capability of numerically simulating acoustic logging is a prerequisite for improving data inversion techniques, such as the computational estimation of the spatial distribution of elastic formation properties from given borehole acoustic measurement. Such numerical modeling can be also used to estimate the acoustic properties of the acoustic logging tool itself, and in turn, can be indirectly used to design such a tool, exhibiting desired behavior under acoustic logging conditions.

Numerical simulation of the borehole acoustic logging is a challenging problem. First, the computational model needs to be sufficiently sophisticated to capture the essential physics (coupling of acoustic and isotropic and transversely anisotropic (visco-)elasticity) while remaining computationally tractable. Second, the truncation of the unbounded physical domain to a bounded computational domain requires a special treatment of the truncated boundary to avoid non-physical reflections of outward traveling waves. For this purpose the Perfectly Matched Layer (PML) technique is applied. Third, the accurate resolution of propagating waves requires a sufficiently fine discretization, ideally equipped with some form of estimate of the discretization error.

The main objective of the work and research is to develop the multi-physics simulator for the accurate modeling of wave propagation within a complex rock-formation with use of wireline and logging-while-drilling (LWD) tools. The resulting software is also able to model eccentered tools as well as deviated boreholes.

The methodology that is utilized to achieve this objective is based on computer simulations using some numerical methods. Among them, we consider the self-adaptive hp-Finite Element (FE) Method as one of the most effective methods for multi-physics simulations. This method enables locally varying element sizes (h) and polynomial orders of approximation (p), and it incorporates a self-adaptive hp-refinement strategy that has the fastest possible (exponential) convergence in terms of the associated energy error vs the CPU time.

The resulting parallel two- and three- dimensional software containing over half a million lines of source code is a highly sophisticated and mathematically robust general-purpose software. In order to achieve accurate results in acceptable computational times, we need to perform parallel computations in High Performance Computing (HPC) centers.

The wave propagation problem is posed in the frequency domain. The same problem is calculated for a family of frequencies (typicaly 500), which is well suited for parallel computations. The direct result of the simulation is a Fourier transform of the pressure or displacement calculated at prescribed locations (usually corresponding to the tool receivers). These data are postprocessed using additional methods (e.g. combination of FFT, signal filtering, mode identification using Prony-like and semblance methods) to obtain the dispersion curves and the waveforms.
hp_borehole.pi_institution: Center for Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering

TG-MSS090007.name: TG-MSS090007
TG-MSS090007.project_abstract: Biological materials, many of which contain proteins as an elementary building block, are organized in functional networks, resulting in structures that span many hierarchical levels. The astounding ability of biological materials to integrate disparate properties goes far beyond our current ability in designing and synthesizing engineered materials, which often feature mutually exclusive properties. Our computational project is aimed at bridging analytical theory and experimental observation in order to both explain phenomena and predict behavior of biological hierarchical materials. In the previous year, we have successfully used XSEDE resources to run our massive computational jobs that provide us productive results of the molecular structures of several protein materials such as silk, elastin, collagen and intermediate filament. Specifically, for this renewal, we will continue focus on several representative biological protein materials from a material science perspective and investigate their role in mechanical materials phenomena. Our study will be very comprehensive as we will fully characterize the structure-mechanics relationship of each protein material to understand the molecular mechanism of their mechanics, as well as carry out comparative investigation to understand their unique roles in the corresponding physiological conditions. We will focus on addressing the property of several key materials: (i) collagenous tissues and bone, (ii) beta-sheet rich materials such as silk, and (iii) elastin, and including combinations of the above in so-called protein alloys. We will summarize the result in an integrated and comparative way by using category theory. Those features make the boundary of our study cross different length scales and different species of materials, making our study unique. The result will greatly contributes to our understanding of biomateriomics, which will improve the design of engineering materials. To ensure that we continue to make achievements toward our goal, we need continuum support of the computational resource for massively parallelized large-scale full-atomistic simulations and successive coarse-grained simulations. The computational resources provided by XSEDE resources will enable us to link the hierarchical structures, geometries and chemical interactions to the overall mechanical and failure properties of these materials. We have set up collaborations with multiple experimental groups in all areas of research, which makes our study promising and will lead to increased impact of our work.

A-nano.name: A-nano
A-nano.project_abstract:
We study various aspects of nanostructures (spectroscopic properties,
structural properties, magnetism, transport, etc.) using
state-of-the-art numerical techniques, mostly based on
density-functional theory (DFT). DFT provides a quantum-mechanical
description of the behavior of electrons in matter, once a
self-consistent eigenvalue problem is solved. PARSEC (web site:
www.ices.utexas.edu/parsec/) is the computer code we use in most DFT
calculations. It has been developed in our research group and it is
now a robust and user-friendly code, whose performance is comparable
to the fastest codes used in the DFT community. Our group has
pioneered DFT calculations of semiconductor clusters with several
nanometers in size. In the last few months, we reported
first-principles calculations of silicon clusters with 10,000 atoms,
ten times more than the then existing size limit. Our group has done
seminal contributions to the development of a real-space approach for
pseudopotentials using DFT, and we applied it successfully to a
variety of different systems ranging from crystalline materials to
liquids, surfaces, clusters, and isolated molecules. Employing a
real-space approach is the natural choice for the study of
nanostructures since it avoids many complications inherent to
alternative methods, mostly because it does not use an explicit basis
in the expansion of electronic states. Also, there are few convergence
parameters, and the computer codes can be parallelized in a
straightforward and efficient way by just partitioning the volume of
interest among processors. Some of the subprojects we are executing
now are: electronic transport and spin transport through a metal-metal
junction; evolution of the magnetization as function of number of
atoms in iron clusters; structural and chemical stability of ternary clusters based on the Heusler phases; optical properties of passivated semiconductor
clusters and nanowires; vibrational modes of molecules in electronic
excited states; doping of semiconductor clusters with magnetic atoms; size effects in multiferroic materials.
A-nano.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

A-ices5.name: A-ices5
A-ices5.project_abstract: Many subsurface applications involve the complexity of coupling different state variables and nonlinear constitutive relationships for describing various phenomena such as reactive and multiphase transport.  In this setting, the solution of the linear and nonlinear algebraic system of equations arising from PDE discretizations has been the main computational bottleneck. Generally, this computation requires from 75% to 95% of the computing time.  In particular, unsaturated groundwater flow problems can easily produce very slow convergence of the nonlinear solver.  This can be extremely dramatic for problems in which the subsurface system is undergoing significant changes in pressure and saturation due to the action of wells, BC's, etc. In this project, we emphasize the development of scalable, parallel solvers for multiphase and compositional flow coupled with other physical phenomena such as geomechanics, chemical transport and temperature.
A-ices5.pi_institution: Institute for Computational Engineering and Science

A-ph91.name: A-ph91
A-ph91.project_abstract: We are interested in first principles calculations of graphene sheets, bilayers, and graphene-based materials.  Graphene possesses unique electronic properties that bring up fundamental questions in condensed matter theory, and is currently one of the most studied systems (as well as having potential applications).  Our group is among the world leaders in research in the field, but as deeper questions are addressed we shall need larger computational power. We are grateful that we can use the resources provided by TACC.

TG-CTS070018N.name: TG-CTS070018N
TG-CTS070018N.project_abstract:
The main objective of the proposed research is to develop, verify, and validate an integrated multiscale model for the
investigation of variable density two-phase flows in complex environments. A novel numerical technique based on combination of a particle-based method and standard continuum approach will be developed to study interfacial phenomena of inception, growth and bursting of vapor bubbles, breakup and coalescence of liquid droplets, and interactions of the fluid surface with complex solid boundaries encountered in cooling of electronic devices, hydro-mechanics of propulsion systems, and cavitation.

Numerical modeling of these flow features using traditional mesh-based finite-volume schemes necessitates use of a time-varying adaptive grid to capture the wide range of length and time scales. The increased complexity and associated costs related to the topological changes in the computational grid are absent in the pure mesh-free techniques. However, they suffer from issues related to efficient implementation of advanced multi-physics models. The hybrid computational approach merges the locally `adaptive' nature of the mesh-free approach for interface tracking with the relative `ease' of the Eulerian finite-volume formulation for complex configurations providing an efficient and accurate numerical technique. 

The proposed developments will be performed in an existing unstructured grid finite-volume solver capable of performing large-scale computations of turbulent flows in complex configurations.
This solver was developed under the Department of Energy's Advanced Scientific Computing (ASC) program at Stanford University. %The PI was part of this program from 2000-2005 and has demonstrated high efficiency and speedup of the solver. 
The basic algorithm will be further developed to address simulations of turbulent flows at high Reynolds numbers. A number of verification and validation studies on motion of single and multiple particles in turbulent flows is planned. Once completed, this formulation will be used to study particle-turbulence interactions using direct numerical simulation. Interactions of micro-bubbles with turbulent boundary layers is important for drag reduction,  whereas studying motion of solid particles in turbulent channels is necessary to understand the sediment transport process and their effect on landform changes and impact on shipping routes. 

The emphasis of this work will be on generating and analyzing a data set for particle-turbulence interactions to understand the multiscale energy cascade mechanisms. The potential impact of this work will be in the fundamental understanding of two-phase flows and interfacial phenomena in complex environments where it is difficult to obtain detailed experimental data.  This will be a major step forward in large-scale computations of multi-physics turbulent flows. The intellectual merit includes training of two graduate students resulting in significant scholarly articles and educating them in high-performance parallel computing. The PI has received Office of Naval Research (ONR) grant (N00014-06-1-0697) for the above developments.

TG-MCB100139.name: TG-MCB100139
TG-MCB100139.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB100139.project_abstract: The research focus in this XSEDE Computational Proposal involves membrane-associated proteins that span the membrane (transmembrane) or attach to the membrane (peripheral) to transport substrates between cellular organelles and lipid-only membrane models. For lipid-only simulations, we propose to develop models for the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and plasma membrane (PM) in yeast that better represent in vivo membranes. All-atom molecular simulations are proposed for three secondary active transmembrane proteins, i.e., lactose permease (LacY), the sodium-hydantoin transporter (Mhp1), small multidrug resistance transporter (EmrE). The main objective for the LacY research is to use QM/MM methods to understand possible pathways for proton translocation during the proteins transport cycle. For Mhp1, we aim to test a new simulation method that can be used to predict unknown conformations of transmembrane proteins. This protein is an ideal test case because the outward-facing, outward-facing occluded and inward-facing structures have been determined from x-ray diffraction. Studies on EmrE will probe the structure and function of this protein. Another objective is to study the attachment mechanism of Osh4 to ER and PM of yeast. Osh4 is a member of an important class of oxysterol binding protein homologues that transfers sterols and a signaling lipid between organelles. Since all three projects are computationally demanding, the only way we can tackle these projects is to obtain a significant allocation on XSEDE.

TG-CTS160003.name: TG-CTS160003
TG-CTS160003.project_abstract:
Rare earth oxides (REOs) have several favorable properties for catalytic applications and a number of REOs are reducible oxides (their metal atoms exhibit variable valence states) and can thus participate in oxidation reactions, for example, where the selectivity to partial and complete oxidation depends on the specific REO. One important application for REOs is the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to ethane and ethylene. This reaction utilizes methane to produce valuable higher hydrocarbons via a direct route, rather than indirect routes involving the production of CO and H2. While the Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 is one of the most active OCM catalysts to date [1], certain REOs, specifically the sesquioxides Sm2O3 and La2O3 which do not form higher oxides, are the most active single component OCM catalysts [2] In contrast to the sesquioxides, REOs in higher oxidation states and with high oxygen mobility, e.g. CeO2 and Tb4O7, are less efficient OCM catalysts and tend to completely oxidize methane to CO2 [3-5]. Recent research, however, has revealed that Li-doped Tb4O7 converts methane with higher rates and with greater selectivity to C2 products than either Sm2O3 or Li-doped Sm2O3 [6]. The proposed here work involves a systematic computational investigation into how low valence (such as Li+ and Fe2+/3+) and high valence (e.g. Ta5+ and W5+/6+) dopants affect the activity and selectivity of REOs (such as CeO2 and TbO2) in OCM. 

Density functional theory (DFT) has been used to investigate the initial steps and thermodynamics of OCM on pure CeO2 surfaces [7,8]. This work re-examine CeO2 and determine activation barriers and reaction energies for the pathways leading to ethane, ethylene, CO, and CO2. From there, other single-component REO surfaces will be examined, such as Tb4O7. Once preferred pathways have been established on single-component CeO2 and Tb4O7, dopants will be added (in various locations) to determine their effects on critical steps which control the rate and selectivity of OCM. Overall, this project will identify the critical steps controlling methane oxidation versus methane coupling over these REO catalysts and identify which properties can promote or suppress the surface reduction (methane oxidation) reaction.

DFT calculations will be performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) with plane waves constructed using projector augmented-wave (PAW) potentials. The revised Per-dew-Burke-Ernzerhof (RPBE) form of the generalized gradient approximation will be used to determine exchange and correlation energies. Traditional DFT methods do not accurately treat the 4f orbitals in Ce atoms, so the DFT + U method will be employed with a value of U = 5 eV, as done in previous studies [7,8]. These calculations will be done in collaboration with Dr. David Hibbitts, also at the University of Florida, who has compiled and tested VASP on the Stampede supercomputer. 

[1] Arndt S, Otremba T, Simon U, Yildiz M, Schubert H, Schomacker R, Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2 as catalyst for the oxidative coupling of methane. What is really known? Applied Catalysis A 425-426 (2012) 53-61.
[2] Tong Y, Rosynek M, Lunsford J, Secondary reactions of methyl radicals with lanthanide oxides  their role in the selective oxidation of methane. Journal of Physical Chemistry 93 (1989) 2896-2898.
[3] Dedov A, Loktev A, Moiseev I, Aboukais A, Lamonier J, Filimonov I, Oxidative coupling of methane catalyszed unexpected synergistic effect by the rare earth oxide mixture. Applied Catalysis A 245 (2003) 209-220.
[4] Otsuka K, Jinno K, Morikawa A, The catalysts active and selective in oxidative coupling of methane. Chem. Letters 4 (1985) 499-500.
[5] Forlani O, Rossini S, Rare-earths as catalysts for the oxidative coupling of methane to ethylene. Materials Chemistry and Physics 31 (1992) 155-158.
[6] Elkins TW, Neumann B, Baumer, M and Hagelin-Weaver, HE, Effects of Li Doping on MgO-Supported Sm2O3 and TbOx Catalysts in the Oxidative Coupling of Methane. ACS Catalysis, 2014. 4(6): p. 1972-1990.
[7] Mayernick A, Janik M, Methane oxidation on Pd-Ceria: A DFT study of the mechanism over PdxCe1-xO2, Pd, and PdO. Journal of Catalysis 278 (2011) 16-25.
[8] Kircha M, Mayernick A, Janik M, Periodic trends of oxygen vacancy formation and C-H bond activation over transition metal-doped CeO2 (1 1 1) surfaces. Journal of Catalysis 923 (2012) 103-115.

TG-MCB150054.name: TG-MCB150054
TG-MCB150054.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB150054.project_abstract: We request XSEDE allocations to study the Ras family of surface-bound proteins that regulate a variety of cell signaling pathways and LAT proteins involved in TCR-mediated signaling.  Malfunction of Ras proteins leads to many forms of cancer and developmental disorders, and there is an urgent need for therapeutic agents to abrogate defective Ras signaling. As part of our broader effort toward developing effective anti-cancer therapeutics by directly targeting Ras, we propose to conduct large-scale molecular dynamics simulations to study the structure, dynamics and druggability of Ras monomers and oligomers in solution and membrane environments. We will also investigate the roles of trans-membrane length, palmitoylation and amino acid sequence in determining membrane domain preferences and dimerization of LAT.
TG-MCB150054.pi_institution: University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston

Scramjet-combustion.name: Scramjet-combustion
Scramjet-combustion.project_abstract:
Motivated by the nature of flows inside scramjet engines, we ask the following question:
Can we use thermal nonequilibrium that is naturally present in the flow to fundamentally
alter the performance of the engine? There is evidence that vibrationally excited molecules have very different reaction rates than predicted by conventional chemical
kinetics models developed for gas-phase combustion. Vibrational nonequilibrium also
leads to thermal energy transport and deposition to regions of the flow far from the source of vibrational excitation. This energy exchange could affect turbulent mixing, and hence the fundamental structure of turbulent flames. We hypothesize that these combined effects of modified chemistry and energy exchange across scales will fundamentally alter
the Kolmogorov turbulence cascade as well as models used for the flame structure in
both non-premixed and premixed systems. We further argue that creating vibrational
nonequilibrium in a flow may provide a means to control reaction rates thereby facilitating favorable reactions or inhibiting undesirable ones.

We will explore the use of vibrational nonequilibrium as a means to control reacting gasphase systems with applications ranging from materials synthesis to scramjet combustion. The program has two main targets: 1) Understanding the laminar flame structure in diffusion flames, when one of the flow streams is vibrationally activated, and 2) understanding the impact of vibrational nonequilibrium on the turbulence energy cascade and flame propagation in turbulent flames. Current experimental and computational tools are inadequate to isolate thermal nonequilibrium effects from other interactions. We propose to use high-fidelity Raman measurements to quantify the degree of vibrational nonequilibrium. Laser diagnostic tools will be used to characterize this flame structure under varying levels of nonequilibrium. Since even these measurements only provide limited access to the flame physics, direct numerical simulations (DNS) will be used to analyze the energy cascade and vibrational energy transfer. A novel inhomogeneous master equation method will be developed to couple quantum chemistry computations to macroscopic flame simulations.
Scramjet-combustion.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-ATM130003.name: TG-ATM130003
TG-ATM130003.project_abstract: In response to the emerging research needs identified by National Research Council and Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, with support from NSF, we are developing an Integrated Technology-Driven Earth System Model (ITDEaSM) to link technology options, energy use, and policy choices and resultant emissions with Earth system processes that govern climate change, air quality, water quality, and ecosystem.  ITDEaSM will be developed by coupling and adding capability to a suite of community models to address grand challenges in decadal regional climate predictions and fill in major gaps in existing climate, Earth system, and ecosystem modeling.  Multi-decadal simulations will be performed using ITDEaSM to estimate the long-term impacts of global climate changes on the global-through-urban earth system, including air quality, water quality/supply, forest, and ecosystem.  Our ultimate goal is to quantify such impacts, reduce associated uncertainties, and identify technology choices for co-benefits of climate/Earth system mitigation. During this 1-year allocation time period, our work will focus on model improvement, testing, and initial applications, which will be conducted by 4 post-Ds and 8 graduate students in our project team.  A complex Earth system model like ITDEaSM requires significant high performance computing resources.  To achieve our goals, we request 5,000,000 SUs for computation (4,000,000 SUs on Kraken and 1,000,000 SUs on Ranger) and 50,000 SUs for Nautilus.
TG-ATM130003.pi_institution: North Carolina State University at Raleigh

TG-MCB080116N.name: TG-MCB080116N
TG-MCB080116N.project_abstract:
This project will focus on the energetics of the sequence of
  electronic transitions in bacteria resulting in the separation of
  charge across the membrane caused by the absorption of a photon of
  visible light. We will run classical MD trajectories of the
  bacterial reaction center in order to extract two types of
  information: dynamics of the fluctuations of the donor-acceptor
  energy gap for the electronic hops and the equilibrium distributions
  of energy gaps. The latter will provide us with the free energy
  surfaces of electronic hopping transitions directly used in the
  calculation of the reaction rates.  The main question we address in
  this study is the details of the mechanism by which natural systems
  eliminate wasteful recombination rates allowing quantum efficiency
  exceeding 99&. This information will be used to formulate practical
  suggestions for photosynthetic conversion of light energy applicable
  to artificial photosynthesis.

Fine-Tuning-CNNs.name: Fine-Tuning-CNNs
Fine-Tuning-CNNs.project_abstract: Computer vision research on object, pose, scene, and activity understanding, leveraging deep convolutional neural networks

A-go3.name: A-go3
A-go3.project_abstract: A large number of numerical experiments will be conducted to understand global and regional changes of climate, water, ecosystems, and environment under global warming.

TG-OCE130016.name: TG-OCE130016
TG-OCE130016.project_abstract: This allocation request is for performing simulations of fine-scale mixing brought about by submesoscale processes (horizontal scale of 100 m - 10 km) which provide pathways to three-dimensional, small-scale turbulence and mixing from eddy kinetic energy and potential energy stored around density fronts. The novelty is the use of turbulence-resolving, high-resolution simulations that enable accurate characterization of small-sale processes including dissipation and mixing that are not resolved by the application of global climate models to submesoscale ocean processes. The new results on the mixing of the upper-ocean stratification by stratified, rotating turbulence will contribute to progress in our existing NSF-funded grants. A startup allocation (Submesoscale Mixing in the Ocean, TG-OCE110017) was awarded last year and results from the large-scale simulations performed using this allocation were included in a paper that was submitted to the Journal of Fluid Mechanics \cite{AroboneS:2013} The new simulations proposed here, by inclusion of a horizontal buoyancy gradient and associated vertical shear, are a natural progression of those conducted with the startup allocation. Barotropic shear flow, a feature that is prevalent in boundary currents and estuarine flows, has remained unexplored in previous investigations of submesoscale frontal dynamics and its inclusion will fill the existing knowledge gap.

TG-EAR080022N.name: TG-EAR080022N
TG-EAR080022N.project_abstract: The Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG), an NSF center, develops and maintains open-source geodynamics software in support of the NSF-supported Earth science community. The goal of CIGs efforts is to provide software that will help researchers and students address important unsolved problems in geophysics, including problems in mantle dynamics, crustal and lithospheric dynamics on both million-year and earthquake time-scales, and seismic wave propagation. CIG engaged in these activities under an MRAC and requested to upgrade to an LRAC in January 2008, as the positive response from the community has been consuming its present TeraGrid allocation at a substantially higher rate than anticipated. This proposal justification will answer questions and address issues raised by the LRAC Review Board. In the previously submitted LRAC application, CIG proposed to continue to promote four geodynamics codes through operation and further development of its science gateway and by pre-installing more codes in TeraGrids Community Software Area. The Seismology Science Gateway, already deployed, features SPECFEM3D_GLOBE, a spectral-element code that simulates global and regional (continental-scale) seismic wave propagation; SPECFEM3D, which simulates southern California seismic wave propagation, is a planned future addition. Three CIG finite-element codes (CitcomS, Gale, and PyLith) are all state-of-the art and scale well on a variety of TeraGrid platforms. Using a powerful, yet simplified interface that will run and benchmark these applications via a web browser, we hope to increase the ability of the Earth Sciences community to access TeraGrid resources. A benchmarking tool, the CIG Model Analyzer (Cigma), will also be offered as a web service. An allocation is requested for four activities: (1) operation and continued development of the science gateway, (2) benchmarking, (3) workshops and training sessions, and (4) nurturing new users on the TeraGrid using CIG software.

TG-MCB150085.name: TG-MCB150085
TG-MCB150085.project_abstract:
The goal of this study is to design the sequences of 4 DNA strands that would form a fluorescent 4-stranded DNA associate, named OC complex with a pre-set melting temperature.  OC complexes are assemblies similar to the X-shaped Holliday junctions except that one of the DNA strands of the OC complex adapts a circular form. As such, the structural differences between the OC complexes and the Holliday junctions are expected to be significant and the DNA sequence effects on the structure and stability of the OC complex are poorly understood. We propose to study the stability of several OC complexes with different sequences at various temperatures.  The computational study will be paralleled by the experimental studies of the same OC complexes.

In the proposed design, two of the DNA strands are labeled with a fluorescent and a quencher moieties. In the assembled OC complex, the labels are located near each other and the fluorescence is quenched. In the melted complex, the strands fall apart and the fluorescent label produces visually detectable light. The sharp cooperative melting curve of the OC complex allows to use the system as a temperature indicator.

We will study the OC complexes by means of all-atom molecular dynamics simulations, performed by NAMD. A solvated OC-complex results in a system of 200-300 thousand atoms, depending on the exact lengths of the DNA strands involved. Based on NAMD benchmarks for Stampede CPUs, we estimate that the requested 200,000 SUs will allow us to conduct 400 nanoseconds (ns) worth of MD. We will simulate two trial OC complex sequences, at 3 different temperatures each, resulting in 67 ns of MD sampling per system at each temperature. While such sampling of the OC complex conformational space will be incomplete (our preliminary simulations indicate that several hundred ns would be required for complete sampling), it will still give us a rough idea of the conformational ensemble and structural stability of the studied OC complexes at each temperature, and allow us to compare the simulation trends with experimental results.

In case of encouraging results, a request for research allocation will be submitted to XSEDE, with the goal of a more thorough conformational ensemble sampling of the studied complexes along the temperature curve, as well as broadening the study into OC complexes with other DNA sequences.

TG-CTS080041N.name: TG-CTS080041N
TG-CTS080041N.project_abstract:
Sustaining the continued growth of civil aviation is critically dependent on limiting its environmental impact. Currently, aviation environmental regulations focus on two main areas: emissions and noise. To date, emissions regulations have focused on air quality impacts near the ground, but increased emphasis on preventing anthropogenic climate change will likely regulate other emissions in the near future. Noise regulations have become incrementally more stringent as air traffic has increased and will likely continue to do so in the future. This project seeks to improve understanding of emissions processes that are unique to aircraft (specifically, condensation trails or contrails) and to improve prediction techniques for airframe noise generation and propagation.

While the impacts of some emissions on climate are well understood (for example, carbon dioxide), the effect of contrails and aircraft induced cloudiness is very uncertain. As part of this project, Large Eddy Simulations (LES) of aircraft wakes, including contrail modeling, will investigate the sensitivity of contrail formation and evolution to a variety of parameters. The data produced by these simulations will help develop more accurate parameterized models of contrails to be used in large-scale atmospheric and climate calculations. 

Airframe noise is associated with the unsteady turbulent flow around the aircraft. Its most significant sources for a landing configuration are high-lift components and landing gears. The aerodynamic flows past these geometries give rise to noise sources at a broad range of frequencies and spatial scales. As part of this project, the computation of noise sources generated by airframe configurations will be carried out by LES. The data produced by the simulations will be used for the prediction of airframe noise and for the improvement of techniques for noise mitigation.

TG-MCA09X003.name: TG-MCA09X003
TG-MCA09X003.project_abstract:
Having constructed a scalable code capable of evolving astrophysically
relevant systems including magnetized neutron stars and black holes,
we request time to continue our runs towards further understanding of
these strong field phenomena. In particular, our code uses MPI and
AMR to make efficient use of large scale computational resources
as well as advanced computational techniques such as higher order
finite differencing, high resolution shock capturing for
magnetohydrodynamics, and black hole excision  in order to evolve
such systems while extracting useful information about the produced
gravitational wave signatures. Further efforts are underway to 
increase the scalability as well as add the ability to track
radiation transport.

TG-DMR160051.name: TG-DMR160051
TG-DMR160051.project_abstract: One of the major challenges in developing clean, environment friendly energy technologies such as solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) is performance degradation at higher temperatures. The surface of the SOFC cathode typically made from perovskite-related oxides. Under operating conditions of SOFCs, one of the major concerns is cathode degradation. In particular, cation segregation on perovskite oxide surfaces impacts tremendously the reactivity and stability of solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) cathodes. The slow rate of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), which is generally agreed to be limited by the surface exchange reactions on mixed ionic electronic conducting cathodes, imposes the main barrier for implementation of high-performance SOFCs at intermediate temperatures (5001000 C). The surface structure and chemistry are driven dynamically by the surrounding environments at a given temperature-pressure conditions. Therefore to attain highly reactive and stable cathode surfaces for fast ORR kinetics, it is important to tailor the catalytic activity of transition-metal oxide cathode with a thorough knowledge of the surface composition and effect of surrounding chemical environments. Density functional theory based computational study may provide a comprehensive picture of the interaction between real-world chemical environments (such as O2 environment, moisture - and CO2 -containing air) which play a crucial role in the electrode performance degradation in lanthanum manganite based SOFC cathodes. In addition to providing insights on the surface chemistry, this computational investigation opens pathways for designing new materials with enhanced catalytic functionality.

A-ti71.name: A-ti71
A-ti71.project_abstract:
The objective of this Research is to develop a research framework and produce a computation toolset to address coronary artery flow problems.  The items that are necessary to build such predictive models are as follows: 

1)	Incompressible Navier-Stokes fluid solver including non-Newtonian constitutive capabilities and, in particular, the Casson model.
2)	Scalar advection-diffusion equation coupled to the Navier-Stokes solver.
3)	Linear elastic/viscoelastic/poroelastic wall and solid capability coupled to the flow solver.
4)	Inflow boundary condition module based on the Womersley solution for distributing the flow waveform over the cross-sectional area of the artery, catheter, etc.
5)	Outflow impedance boundary condition module to represent the effect of the distal arterial system on the modeled region.
6)	Non-uniform rational B-spline (NURBS) templates for accurate geometric modeling and meshing of lumen and surrounding tissue.
7)	Mesh generation capability.

With these items, meaningful calculations can be carried out, and also, it will provide a framework for future development.  At the moment our research group has a finite element and NURBS based Navier-Stokes solver and coupled linear elastic solid capability and a capability to generate finite element meshes for it.  We have added the Casson model to the flow solver, developed the coupled advection-diffusion equation capability, the poroelastic solid capability and develop the NURBS templates and the other items listed. 

Now we will study mass transport within the blood vessel wall with a view to achieving a few specific objectives:
 
ï¿½	A study of the coupled analysis of mass-transport of nano-particles and drug in the blood stream and in the arterial walls will be undertaken. Results of this study will be incorporated into the existing computational framework in order to investigate,

a)	Mass transport of drug-encapsulated nano-particles into the blood vessel wall 
b)	Coupled mass transport of nano-particles and drug diffusion from nano-particles in the arterial wall 

given several boundary conditions, namely, mass flux, concentration of drug at the wall, and so on. 

ï¿½	On the analysis side, our efforts will include, 
a)	Quantification and visualization of drug concentration on the arterial wall as a function of space and time 
b)	Studying the parametric sensitivity of mass transport 
c)	Determination of dominant dimensionless numbers (Schmidt number, Sherwood number, etc.)
d)	Defining metrics (for example, dose homogeneity index, remaining mass percentage, etc.) to measure drug delivery efficiency, and thus effectiveness of various catheter systems.

This request seeks to validate the software we have developed and start testing on some patient-specific geometries the efficacy of different drug delivery systems.
A-ti71.pi_institution: Department of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics

TG-DMR150099.name: TG-DMR150099
TG-DMR150099.project_abstract:
This is a new proposal for an XSEDE research allocation, which will support the research on
computational modeling of advanced materials in the group of Prof. Anderson Janotti in the
Department of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Delaware (UD). The
computational resources will be used to perform electronic structure calculations for a series
of functional materials which are the focus of research grants funded by the Department
of Energy, University of Delaware, and the National Science Foundation (a research
proposal is currently being prepared for submission to the Division of Materials Research).

First-principles calculations, based on the density functional theory, constitute a
powerful tool to investigate the structural, electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of
materials. These calculations have greatly contributed to fundamental understanding of
the electronic structure of materials and the response to mechanical, electric, magnetic, and
optical excitations. The materials that are the focus of this project are complex oxides, Heusler
and half-Heusler compounds, and layered chalcogenide materials. The goal is to understand
the fundamental relationship between chemical composition, structure, electronic,
and transport properties of these materials, in close connection to current experimental
work at UD and elsewhere.

These studies employ advanced algorithms that necessarily demand the use of highperformance
parallel computation. Prof. Janotti has demonstrated extensive experience in
the area of computational materials science, with emphasis on first-principles calculations,
and has established a strong record in the areas of doping and defects in oxide and nitride
semiconductors, semiconductor surfaces and interfaces, hydrogen impurities in materials,
and complex-oxide heterostructures.

TG-DPP130002.name: TG-DPP130002
TG-DPP130002.project_abstract:
We request a one-year allocation of 11.73 million SUs on TACC's
Stampede system in support of our NSF/DOE/AFOSR-funded research on
Bayesian inverse problems and applications to quantifying
uncertainties in models of Antarctic ice sheet dynamics.

This project aims at improving the understanding of the dynamics of
polar ice sheets through solution of Bayesian inverse problems to
infer uncertain ice sheet model parameters from observed surface flow
data, employing advanced high resolution forward
simulations. Sensitivities of ice flow to unknown model parameter
fields, such as the ice viscosity and the basal sliding coefficient,
are determined through solution of adjoint ice flow models. The goal
is to incorporate observations from a diversity of sources, for
example surface ice velocities obtained from InSAR surveys and ice
sheet geometry information acquired from airborne altimetry and
ice-penetrating radar, to quantify uncertainties in the inference of
the basal sliding coefficient and rheological parameters.

The knowledge that we will gain through solution of these inverse
problems will improve the confidence in estimates of future changes
in the dynamics and mass balance of polar ice sheets, and thus the
accuracy of predictions of future sea levels in climate change
projections. This has been an exceedingly difficult task in the past
(and indeed was left of out future climate projections of the IPCC 4th
Assessment report due to large uncertainties and challenges in
modeling continental ice sheet dynamics). 

To this end we have developed a state of the art ice sheet simulator
with multiple advanced features: complex boundary conforming
representation; high order finite element approximation; mass
conservative discretization; parallel dynamic mesh adaptivity and load
balancing; scalable Newton-Krylov-multigrid solver; adjoint-based
sensitivities; inexact Newton inversion; and fast Gaussianized
uncertainty quantification capabilities. The ice sheet simulator has
been scaled to over 100K cores on ORNL's Jaguar system, and in
friendly user testing to 16K cores on Stampede. We are now in a
position to employ these capabilities to infer uncertainties in the
dynamics of the Antarctic ice sheet via Bayesian inversion.

TG-CHE140071.name: TG-CHE140071
TG-CHE140071.project_abstract: Enzyme Cytochrome P450 and coenzyme vitamin B12 have similar physical and bio-chemical features of their activation mechanisms due to their similar structures. Both molecules are activated by the influence of the substrate or by the influence of the electronic transfer. The special effect similar to Pseudo-Jahn-Teller effect is responsible for the activation of these bio-systems. DFT, MCSCF and single point CCSD(T) electronic structure methods are expected to identify both,  the structural mechanisms and the vibronic e. g. Pseudo-Jahn-Teller effect influence on coenzyme vitamin B12 coenzyme and enzyme porphyrin P450 activation in multiple biological processes.

TG-MCB120050.name: TG-MCB120050
TG-MCB120050.field_of_science: Biochemistry and Molecular Structure and Function
TG-MCB120050.project_abstract: The thermodynamics of lipid-protein interactions is a fundamental driving force for processes involving membrane proteins and membrane-active peptides. Even though membrane proteins constitute ~25% of open reading frames throughout all kingdoms of life, very little is quantitatively known about the physical basis of their folding and stability. We plan a large set of molecular dynamics computations aimed at discovering how membrane proteins and membranes adapt to sequence changes introduced on the lipid-facing surface of membrane proteins. The proposed work includes 3 broad computational projects: (1) determine the structural consequences to both the membrane and the protein in response to mutations on the proteins lipid-facing surface; (2) reconcile the disparity between computational and experimental free energies of partitioning of amino acid side chains at a central position in the bilayer; and (3) determine the influence of the local environment on the structure and energetic consequences of charged mutations by classical MD and free energy perturbation calculations.

TG-DMR150095.name: TG-DMR150095
TG-DMR150095.project_abstract: Silicon, the most widely used material in current transistor technologies is reaching its fundamental scaling limits. In0.53Ga0.47As (InGaAs), a pseudo-alloy of InAs and GaAs with an electron mobility at least seven times higher than Silicon (Si), is considered a strong candidate for higher performing and energy efficient electronic devices. In this project, we are interested in studying the diffusion of Si, the most promising dopant for n-type transistor channel materials, in InGaAs. Previous experimental results suggest that Si has a concentration-dependent and relatively low diffusivity in InGaAs. When completed, this computational study will provide valuable atomistic-level insights and help explain the reasons for this poorly understood low reported diffusivity as well as its connection to dopant activation. A combination of first-principle calculations and Kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) methods are used to elucidate the primary diffusion mechanism under different conditions, understand the reason for low reported diffusion in literature and calculate the diffusion coefficient.
